So this show really is gonna be up to if you like Akko or not. I love her, but I don't know everyone would like her. She is brash, loud, but has such a huge drive and passion that makes me want to root for her. So, I believe she is an affective main character. 


In closing this show is amazing and desperately needs a season 2. I won't spoil, but I will say it didn't end like Kill la Kill. that isn't to say Kill la kill's ending was bad or anything. I am just telling you this show has more to tell and I know me and others want to see more.

One of the best anime I've seen in the last 12 months.
I love magic anime, I find it almost educational. But this is basically a Japanese anime version of "the worst witch", with elements of Harry Potter (kid gets drawn into adventures due to the misbehaviour of adults, saves the day, and eventually gets recognised for their talents).
It's kids stuff, but with much MUCH deeper meanings than the afformentioned shows. As a practitioner of magick, and someone who likes to study the theory behind it, the meanings behind 7 words are actually startlingly accurate for anyone who goes through initiation/magickal growth.
As such, by the endof this anime I found myself sad that only 25 episodes were made, but satisfied by it all. I think it ended too quickly, there was so much more character growth that could of happened, there were characters who needed more expansion, and some I think needed to be introduced.\n\n
The ending, well, it was beautiful, it was typical anime pat, but from the experiences we had had, Akko's seemingly annoying enthusiasm and ponkotsu (clumsy) nature - well, I'll just say it pays off.\n\n
In conclusion, this is a light hearted magical romp, that has a beautiful message behind it, and a very satisfying final episode.

This anime is just wow. The characters feel so real, they all develop so well over the course of the show, the whole time you're routing for them. The show makes you feel like you too can do anything as long as you never give up and stay true to your dreams. There are the ups and downs throughout the series and nothing feels forced, the story flows so naturally and it makes for very pleasant viewing.
If you want a show that; can keep you engaged, fill you with motivation and positivity, give you a beautiful way to escape the everyday and feel pure emotion,make 20 minutes seem like 5, rip you heart out and then tenderly heal it back in place, have your routing for the characters and wanting them to be friends - wanting to find out more about them, well then this is the show for you, what more is to be said.\n\n
This is one of the only shows that can regularly send a shiver down my spine and I highly recommend it.

Little Witch Academia is most certainly not the most original story in the world. It does follow a lot of overused tropes that you would find in a million other stories. However there is just so much charm here that it manages to somewhat make up for the show's general predictability. It never feels soulless and that is largely due to its incredibly likeable cast of characters.
 Atsuko Kagari is a generic yet lovable protagonist. It is easy to get invested in her ambition and drive, but she is not the perfect hero at all, being incredibly clumsy and well...not exactly the smartest characterout there. That said, it never gets to the point of being annoying or unsympathetic (in fact I found it largely entertaining) making her overall worth rooting for.\n
 The supporting cast is mostly solid as well with standouts including the entertaining sociopath Sucy Manbavaran, the intriguing badass Ursula Callistis and my personal favourite Diana Cavendish, whom I found to be easily the most fascinating and well developed character in the show, whose efforts and dedication were truly admirable. Additionally, Little Witch Academia features an excellent villain, who managed to strike just the right balance between delightfully despicable and genuinely sympathetic.\n
 Sadly, it is not a perfect cast. There are a few characters about whom I honestly did not care much for. Like Lotte Yansson, who just did not offer much outside of being the token cute one. Diana's two friends were unbearably annoying and unlikeable and most of Luna Nova's staff members were rather forgettable (with some obvious exceptions like the previously mentioned Ursula).\n
 On the technical side, the show has a lovely soundtrack. Can't comment on Japanese voice acting because I have only seen the dub (please don't sue me) but it is actually mostly good.\n
 As expected from Trigger, the art style is absolutely gorgeous and the animation is excellent (when it's not a bit choppy).\n
 The shot composition is rather spot on too, with the vast majority of the shots giving the viewer something interesting and/or nice to look at making the anime a very visually appealing one.\n
 Overall, Little Witch Academia is a lot of fun. Far from a masterpiece but it is just such an easily lovable show. I highly recommend watching it if you have not already. Especially if you are a fan of magical school kind of stories, but that goes without saying.

Plot/story 9/10
The story is based around Akko Kagari, a young girl who wants to become a witch like her idol Shinning Chariot, even though she has no witch blood in her. Akko is on her way to Luna Nova Witch Academia. During her stay at Luna Nova, Akko befriends 2 students, Lotte, and Sucy. The episodes progress well to meet the plot, but there were a few things that didn’t quite fit or kind of just jumped out. The overall story was well written and left behind a great and deeper meaning.
Art 8/10
Visually it looks very good for the most part, but the characters withthe exception of Sucy look very similar in size and body shape. The background drawings are well detailed and drawn. It is very well animated.


Sound 9/10

The soundtrack is mainly made up of instrumental piece, that are very beautifully played. In my opinion the ending and opening themes we slightly slow, but fit very well with the story.

The voice acting for both sub and dub was very good.


Character 9/10

The characters are amazing and very likeable in their own ways. Akko is an amazing female lead.

She's a very energetic and determined girl who wants to achieve her dreams despite her being an ordinary girl with no witch blood, she also has great character development, especially in the second half. Sucy is unsociable, and very sarcastic and likes to use Akko for her experiments, but I feel she should have gotten more screen time in the second half along with character development. Lotte is very likeable and probably my favorite character, she is very nerdy, and helpful to Akko, but along with Sucy I wish she had more screen time, and character development. Diana is a very serious witch from an extensive line of witches, but unlike Sucy and Lotte, Diana had great character development. There are a few other minor characters, that still had very good roles.


Enjoyment 9/10

I really enjoyed this anime even though it wasn’t my typical anime. For me Little Witch Academia held a greater meaning than what jus meets the eye. While there were a few things that I didn’t quite like with the audio and visual, the characters were great and really pushed the story along. Overall, I found Little Witch Academia very enjoyable. I give it an 8.9/10

This is a show i will not be forgetting anytime soon i can tell you that for sure. 
~~Spoilers~~
 Characters: 
   Akko: Tends to get way too nosy about other peoples business. She has the mentality that if she doesn't think this is what people actually want than she will go and do what she thinks is best for them ( You know, A very annoying character trait) When i compare her to other characters in the show. I just can't really get behind her as the one who is actually deserving of all this attention she gets. We have two other charactersin the show (Diana) (Chariot)  These two are more deserving of these powers cause they actually seem like they have worked for it.


  Diana: At first i thought she was gonna be the typical know it all girl that's also stuck up. But she is my second favorite character in the show actually. She is caring and isn't rude to others. She can be blunt though. But she has spent her entire life working on magic and has put a ton of effort into magic stuff. She even had to go and learn how to do magic all over again. I personally feel that she is a character who is more deserving of the special magic Akko got. 


  Chariot: Is by far my favorite character. I really wish she was the focus of the show and not Akko. By far one of the most interesting stories. Imo more likable than any other character. She also has over of my favorite character designs i'v seen. I also feel that she should have been the one to use the special magical powers and not Akko. She was the original owner of the magical rod. I also feel that the story should have ended on her being the last to use the power .


Art: I love this art style. I feel if it wasn't for the art style i don't think this would have grabbed my attention the first episode. 


~~ Spoilers Over~~ 


I really loved this show. Even if i do get annoyed at times with the MC. This is defiantly gonna be something i remember for awhile .

An easy 10 in my opinion.
Ever since watching the movie i've been wishing they would make an anime, and here it is. I think people who say "this anime is way too overrated" forgot what anime is. It's a vast collection of uncountable genres. Definitely not overrated, but perhaps unappreciated enough.
This anime is for those who want to laugh. Akko, Lotte and Sucy's shenanigans are top notch. They will never leave you bored even for one second.
It's for those with a sense of adventure. Because LWA is a story about wonderful adventures of all of the characters. We even get to see the past ofher rival, Diana, and her own adventure. In that sense the story does not focus only on Akko.

It's for those who love following a character which grows and evolves throughout the anime. (literally all of them)

It's for those who have an open mind and want positivity in their life. 

As easy as that. This anime is nothing but pure good. It brings a warm feeling every time I watch it. And I highly suggest you to watch this anime if you just want to take a break from all those horror/mystery animes.


Story: They made a story, mixed it with some fillers here and there, but nothing really feels like a filler, because our protagonist Akko, is always trying, always learning and always evolving. It feels natural and intriguing. Every few episodes we seem to get closer to what the story actually is about, and I love it! The fact that you can even enjoy the fillers is something which shows how well the show is made.


Art: F.A.N.T.A.S.T.I.C. <--- I'm a sucker for god art and imho this is great. "Trigger" Brings us yet another masterpiece.


Sound: Music is fab. Usually I skip the OP and ED, but I just can't. It's just too good. Michiru Ōshima's hard work really shines here. Check her work out if you have a spare moment!


Character: There's development, small amount of flat characters. Everyone's changing and developing. It's important to notice that Yoh Yoshinari who wrote the Manga also directed the anime, thus bringing it as close to canon as possible, and managed to convey the character's feelings properly. 


Overall: 10/10. I recommend it to anyone! Both beginners and intense anime lovers :D

Contains spoilers. Please excuse my writing, this isn't really something I'm good at but after an experience like this I feel like I need to say something.
A simple girl has a simple dream of meeting her childhood idol. Sounds pretty linear, right? Wrong. It's so much more than that. From a fun little show about a young witch aspiring to bring smiles on people's faces with magic, we got something that might as well be called lessons of life. It's a serious understatement if I say that this show got me by surprise. This review might not be about the show itself as much asabout what it is trying to say. I'm not a creative person so I'll just split this into 7 points, each representing one of the words of Arcturus and what they mean *to me*.


"Those that try to achieve their dreams must go through hardships. There may come times when you fail and lose sight of that dream. But you must never let the flame in your heart go out. Burn that flame brightly, and strive for your ideal place" or Noctu Orfei Aude Fraetor:

First of all I know the "official" translation is "Strive for your ideal place" but I like this version much more. Noctu Orfei Aude Fraetor is the most meaningful word of the 7 for me. Sure, this basically says "never give up" which is a massive cliché at this point but the author's way with the words makes it so much more special. Life has ups as well as downs. It is only natural that sometimes things don't go your way and you feel like giving up on everything. That's why it's important that you never forget what you're going for and keep on fighting. In real life, dreams often don't come true, but one must have faith and find themselves a place in life where they're happy, even if it's not what they dreamed of in the first place.


"You do not get the things that you dream of, you get the things you work for" or Phaidoari Afairynghor:

Pretty similar to the first word in my opinion. I don't think this one needs much more to say. Simply, it's no surprise when your dreams don't come true, because they are not achieved by dreaming but by working and putting in effort. A good reality is much better than an amazing (unreal) desire.


"Do not compare yourself with others, do what only you can do" or Arae Aryrha:

Everyone has their own reality. Everyone perceives life differently. It's what makes us diverse. You can't be good at everything and so can't anybody. You're good at something, that person is good at something else, but they can't do what you can and so on. Comparing yourself with others often ends in thinking that you're worse than everyone around you, because you only see the bright sides and don't realize everybody has their own insecurities however confident they may look.


"To see it through, patience is important" or Mayenab Dysheebudo:

Nothing important in your life ever happens day to day. And it's probably as it should. If you achieved everything immediately could it be even considered an achievement then?


"When traditional and modern powers mingle, the gate to an unseen world will open" or Sybilladura Lelladybura: 

Don't forget where you come from because it's half of who you are. Too much of anything is bad so the balance between what was, what is, and what will be needs to be found in order to see new things you didn't realize before. 


"Thank you" or Lyonne:

Simplest and shortest one, yet crucial. I admit, sometimes I'm guilty of not going by this. It often seems unnecessary and insignificant. To express gratefulness to ones that helped you on your way is the smallest thing you can do for them, yet it can mean a great deal. Saying thank you is the tiny bit of magic we actually do have in this world.


"Connect with other people, and your dreams will grow" or Phasansheer Shearylla:

You can barely achieve anything by yourself. While it's true it is you who needs to be persistent in order to move somewhere further, it is highly unlikely you can do so without people you value.


Hopefully this wasn't as boring as it looks. In conclusion, I value this show greatly, it had the right amount of just everything. I overuse the word "literally" quite a bit but when I say LWA is literally flawless I mean it. There wasn't a minute when I was bored, it always had something to offer. Earlier on it was light-hearted comedy, later the story and characters started to develop etc. For a time, I felt like I'm part of it, which is something, I seek in everything I watch. I'll miss the show and I'm looking forward to rewatching it sometime. Obviously 10/10.

Little Witch Academia TV is another instance where Studio Trigger has completely stolen my heart, and whisked me away into a beautiful adventure to see some of the most amazing moments in entertainment media as a whole, and Trigger carries it without breaking a sweat with their smooth, breathtaking animation.
The art style, even though the shading has taken a downgrade from the movie and short to compensate time for the rush of making a TV anime, is still just as breathtaking, and some shots for me outdo the movie and short in its entirety.
The story is heartwarming. I cried from the happy feeling I feltin some episodes... And from the sad in others. As most Trigger anime do, it made me quite emotional with it's impactful moments.\n
The sound design continued to stun me. During fights I could hear the quality of the sounds they had in full force... I'll save the details for your watch.\n
Each character managed to make me smile at least once. I find them all interesting in their own way, and love them all equally and I hope they all have safe and loving lives ahead of them.\n
I enjoyed this anime very much, and its a breath of fresh air compared to the fanservice, or cliches the rest of the industry is offering right now. The messages the anime gave me with each episode was beautiful and it filled me with joy to see Yoh's talent as a director and writer...\n
With all that said... I think Yoh did a flawless job. 10/10.\n
Please, if you have Netflix... Watch it there. Trigger needs as much support as it can get. If you can then buy the blurays even.\n
Thank you for reading and enjoy the show.\n
Its showtime.

Summarizing my thoughts on Little Witch Academia, I was interested in the premise of the show since I have enjoyed stories that involved witches and wizards in the past. However in the end, I was left feeling that the anime was just ok.
The story, while not bad, did not do much in drawing me in. There wasn't much story progression until the second half of the anime with the first half mainly consisting of slice of life moments centered around the lives of the young witches at the academy as they learned the Ins and Outs of magic.
The art and animation is instantly recognizable asthat of Studio Trigger and in this regard I felt like it was both beautiful and unique.\n
There were good characters in Little Witch Academia although they were a little bit cliche in the way they were portrayed and in how they interacted with each other.\n
Even though this anime has a lot of good points to it, I simply wasn't able to enjoy the show overall. So in closing I can recommend that Little Witch Academia is at least worth giving the first couple episodes a try to see whether it would be one for you or not.

This is an abomination.
This anime has been compared to My Hero Academia left and right, but I'm not seeing it. Aside from an underdog kid being put in a special school, there's like, no similarities. Hero Aca starts off by actually introducing the main characters instead of showing some cookie-cutter bullshit flashback that doesn't answer the  important question of "how is the character changed in this moment". That's what a flashback is supposed to do, but instead, it just says "Girl thinks magic is cool, fuck you". Hero Aca is boring in the beginning, but it serves its purpose and substantially increases the longevityof the show. Witch Aca, however, decides to save the backstory and character development for later and just throw the MC into the fray. Unfortunately, actually caring what happens to the MC is pretty important if you want the viewer to tune in to the next episode. 


The art was fine in this show, but I think it's kind of dull, especially for a show about magic. I see no reason for this show to not be bursting with color when it's not even supposed to be bound by the chains of reality. Also, there are these strange off-putting pauses and shots that last way too long. For instance, the zoom in on the moon from the flashback. That shot went on for 3 seconds too long. 


I hate the main character's voice. In contrast, I think the dull-pink haired girl has a nice, not suicide-provoking voice. Still, fuck the MC's voice.


The characters were the worst thing in the first episode other than the plot, or lack-thereof. For instance, why is the dull-pink haired girl so hostile to the MC without any provocation? Why do the glasses-girl and the MC get along so quickly despite the MC nearly fucking everything up for glasses-girl? Why the hell is the MC so hyper and giddy? I don't even remember the MC and glasses-girl giving proper introductions, but they're calling each other by name in a later scene. Maybe I'd just fallen asleep by that point because the story moves so sloooowwllyyyy. The entire first episode is about the MC's trip to fucking school. 


I feel like my time was intentionally being wasted.


Comparing this to Hero Aca is blasphemy. 8/10 rated; what a joke.


3/10. Wasted potential.

This is my first review. 
I usually don't watch shows that have "witch" in their title. I first decided to watch Little Witch Academia because of the art and color palette used in the poster! And my instinct was spot on. Little Witch Academia's strength is in its art and animation. That is not saying that the story is its weakness but it is lacking in terms of complexity of plot and characterization. 
The main character, Kagari Atsuko, aspires to be a great witch like her idol Shiny Chariot. Although she is an ordinary person (as in not a witch by blood), she tries herhardest to achieve her dream. In these kind of stories, there is always an element of fate or destiny so you can expect a few revelations of that sort eventually. It's a simple stereotype story and its slow pacing doesn't do it any favors. The show so far is mostly episodic but with hints of its overarching plot embedded in each ep so that it won't feel disjointed. Humor is an essential part of the anime. In my opinion it almost changes the main genre from a fantasy to a comedy! The carefree nature of the main character and her silliness affects her surroundings to the point where you can't take the story too seriously and as a result, it redeems its thin and simplistic plot. 

Story: 6 | Fair


Aside for the main character, character development is almost nonexistent in regards to supporting characters. However, the story isn't finished yet, not to forget that it is slow-paced so there's still hope. With hardships on the MC's path, there is bound to be growth of character. no matter how small that develoment is, it is important for the character to reach her goal. She learns that asking for solutions and answers to her problems is too easy and working hard and believing in herself is more rewarding. She also learns that it is okay to do thigns her way instead of comparing herself to others or watning to be exactly like her idol. The same with almost all anime MCs, she doesn't know how to give up; she is stubborn as hell and that's what brings the others around her. 

Characters: 6 | Fair


Art and animation is what brought Kagari to life as well as the world of LWA. The art is what initially attracted me to the anime. It works so well with Kagari that I cannot imagine her character portrayed any other way. the roundish design of the characters as well as the lack of sharp lines help the audience feel at ease watching the anime. I'm never at the edge of my seat because this isn't that kind of show. It's warm,soft, silly and magical. 

The setting is as good as character design. Although, the world of LWA doesn't feel original to me, it doesn't mean that it's not crafted with brilliant imagination. Couple the art with the beautiful and fluid animation and you get an animated magic spectacle. I think that's what the animators were going for. It is important to mention that the high quality of the animation is maintained in every episode unlike most titles these days especially compared to long-running series. 

perhaps it's just me but I think the art and animation are very close to ghibli's style. Well, I'm no expert so i might be wrong.

Art & Animation: 9 | Great


LWA's score is exclusively orchestral which suits the fantasy genre well. There isn't a piece that sticks out but also there isn't one that attracts your attention as being out of place. The whole score meshes well with the animation and story. There might have been an instance where they used a classical piano piece in-script and it served as score for a sequence where Kagari chases after a mosquito which was cool. OP & ED also fit the story and the nature of the anime. Personally I'm not very fond of the songs but I do like the animation. 

Sound: 7 | Good


Little Witch Academia was able to make me forget the real world for 20 mins every episode and show me a great spectacle of animation which I rarely see with such consistency nowadays (last one i've seen was Mod Psycho 100). It's the title's redeeming feature. Without such art and animation style, I bet LWA would have been a medioce bore. 

Enjoyment: 8 | Great


Sorry for the messy structure. I was never good at writing but i can't get better without actually writing so there you have it, my first review. any ideas or feedback is appreciated. thank you for reading. 

OVERALL: 7 | Good

While the title may make the anime seem promising, the anime fails to deliver the suspense needed to carry this anime to the top.
Much of the earlier part of the anime can be interpreted as fillers, giving viewers the notion that this anime is silly, episodic, about the whacky(?) adventures of Akko and friends. While it does serve the purpose of character building, I fail to get emotionally attached to any of the characters. 
In its redeeming faith however, what seemed like a inane, pointless story about the episodic adventures of Akko and friends is that- at the 21st episode- all the plot holes andseemingly silly hyperbolic things seen in the previous episodes are all explained.

Each person has different reasons to see or read a story that caught their attention. Some are based on the poster, trailer or character design, others on the staff in charge, producer or studio that does it. Whatever the reason, we all have a weakness to see that the story will contain a certain element that we love. In this case, I personally like stories with witches and that's why when I saw that Trigger's OVAS were going to have an anime, it was my priority to see it, now let's see if Little Witch Academia fulfilled its purpose.
What is Little Witch Academy about?
Atsuko Kagari(Akko) is a girl whose only desire is to become a witch like her idol Shiny Chariot. That's why she enrolled in the Luna Nova Academy of Witchcraft, to learn and become as great as her. Its only drawback is that she is useless for magic to such an extent that she can not do the simplest things like flying or using basic spells. Although not all is lost because on her first day Chariot's rod appears and decides that from that moment she will try her best to fulfill her dream.


A story with a questionable rhythm



The whole plot will be handled through an episodic style solving the problem of the week. It may work for you at first because it does not seem to be more than that. Although from the first chapter we can see that at some point it will take the serialized form, which it does, but without leaving the problems of the week. The drawback with this narrative is that the rhythm of the episodes is very inconsistent, some scenarios will have such a construction that when you reach the climax it will feel rushed causing an unsatisfactory conclusion. Some will have a decent pace to have the right time for each moment, but these are a minority with respect to others. At the same time, the series takes time to give consistency to the chapters, it is true that several of the first half have repercussions in the future avoiding creating the Deus ex Machina strictly, however, seeing that most are autoconclusive and that until the second half they appear only to fulfill a purpose, they do not feel so natural. The anticipation is appreciated, but it is still a convenience that could be better used. The chapters are entertaining to watch, in the end they leave you wanting more, although it is more for haste instead of being a good chapter.


The story will use two elements to be interesting and keep the audience: the issues it deals with and the humor. With the first we find several during the entire anime, however, to treat them it falls short. The main one will be to chase for your dreams and that "to believe is your magic", which will rub on your face during most of the chapters. There would be no problem with that but because they say it so directly, it loses the naturalness in the plot and becomes almost a lesson, bordering on what was done before in the cartoons. Others such as traditions, the clash of the traditional with the modern, the vision of witches and magic, all are shown and mentioned on several occasions, but they never have a conclusion that we could consider interesting because they are left to a side or solved conveniently. Luckily, comedy is handled very well, situations, dialogues and reactions are entertaining, managing to get several laughs for their humor. It has to its favor that it is ingenious because each situation is different and a few times will be repeated avoiding saying the same joke several times. The topics covered, despite being left out or be purely exposure without quite naturalness in the plot, along with its humor will manage to keep you in front of the screen if you do not expect much, it is a simple series that fails to become complicated or have depth, but that does not makes it unbearable to watch, because its comedy is more than enough reason to see it.


Simple secondary characters and a hardly acceptable protagonist



The characters are interesting, but they feel like a wasted resource. For now we will leave Akko aside to talk more in depth later. The secondary ones have a unique charisma, however, they leave aside the development. It is true that all, or the great majority, will have their chapter where they will be the focus of attention, but they never say anything relevant about them, they only confirm what we already knew about their personalities. In a matter of development we could only mention Sucy with the chapter when they enter her mind, which gives us an interesting insight into her personality and friendship with Akko. While in evolution we have Diana, who would be the best character in the series. She may have childish motives, but due to her conflicts and situation you can get to empathize with her making the chapters that are dedicated to her the best of the anime. On the other hand, the villain does not appear until the middle of the anime, removing some weight. Besides, her actions become contradictory, at one moment she wants to get rid of her nemesis and the other, she is saving her for sentimental reasons that appear out of nowhere. It's not a joke, you just can not take it as someone who deserves respect, it's a shame that she left a lot to be desired. Finally, in secondaries, we have Ursula, a teacher with a secret that she reveals  and gives way to something that could have been better managed to give a great development, although she is well worked is not the big thing and remains as something mediocre (not good not bad).


Now we have the protagonist, Akko, and all the points, both positive and negative, that comes with her. From the beginning she makes clear her motivations and personality, although this is also where the problems begin. Throughout the series she will remain the same, they will never show us anything more of her, all her actions and decisions will be related to her like for magic and admiration towards Chariot. It would not be bad if it were not because she never changes, even with the revelation mentioned above does not seem to have some kind of change in her attitude. It is annoying that during all the time she remains as a one-dimensional character, especially because she is the protagonist, that is, she should be the one who has more construction. Being so short would work if she were a secondary character or if the series did not seek to be taken seriously several times.


Another drawback comes to light with the advance of the episodes, her desire to help quickly go from altruism to obstinacy, because she never listens to reasons and only thinks on what she believes it is right, so that in the end she ends up being right, making her annoying over time, leading to another problem. In many parts Akko seems like a Mary Sue because she is always right, nobody corrects her and when they do it, in the end it turns out that she was right. Apart, all the attention goes to her, this is technically good for being the main character, however, here it happens in an exaggerated way. Everyone asks what she is doing, where she is, if she must do or need something, the vast majority of things happen by or for her, monopolizing all the attention.


The only positive thing that she has, apart from her funny scenes, is her inability to use magic, that over time she improves little by little through effort and will. During conflicts, she manages to use her few resources to get out of difficulties in an ingenious way. Although she has a plot-device that will help her with great magical power, it is not so recurrent to lose the tension and creativity of the moments, even in the end she uses what she learned in the best possible way, so it is a great point to keep in mind in her construction. Akko is someone you love or hate, you can hold it and laugh at her craziness, it's easy to get attached to her, but you could not consider her a good character because of the little construction she has.


Striking technical section



The animation is simply spectacular. Beyond having a good fluency during the combats and the use of magic, the prize takes it as how they use it for humor. In simple terms it would be considered expressive in a caricatured way, much comedy is based on the expressions of the characters and their movements during situations that arise. Each character will be deformed or distorted when moving, this beyond being bad animation is actually part of the crazy and fantastic style that manages. At the same time it will have scenes where the epic will stand out, the parts that have a great attention to detail and that without using CGI manage to make them look so fluid, some even surprise you that it have maintained the traditional animation. Watching the series just for the animation is a good choice because it is a festival of exaggerations and extravagances that impress you and constantly makes you laugh, that is, what more can be expected from the studio that brought us Kill la Kill ?, It may not be that level of madness, it even seems that the quality goes down on some occasions, but Little Witch Academia earns its identity as a worthy anime for Trigger.


As for music, it could not be considered beyond environmental. It has a magical fantasy style that goes well with the whole context. It really is a decent job because it does not end up being flashy, but it is not disposable either, the series would not be the same without it. The openings and endings unfortunately do not pass beyond generic, they may sound good, however, do not excel in any way. As for the section of the soundtrack it does a decent job, it may sound good in some moments becoming more prominent, however, it is better to listen to it with the anime instead of doing it separately.


A fun anime to pass time.


Little Witch Academia is easy to recommend, but not for being good. You can constantly laugh at its excellent comedy and animation, because they are its strongest points. Unfortunately, it remains a lot to be owed for its characters and rhythm in most chapters. Although do not doubt that you can sympathize with the witches, without a doubt, they are charismatic with a funny personality that will make you want more. Reasons to see it are not lacking, it can be enjoyed if you let go of several things, however, its failures become significant enough to not let them pass. This is an anime that is style over substance, it is not bad, but neither could be said otherwise. I would give it a 6.5/10.

Personal Rating: 7 (Good)
Simply put without the 800 word essays like everyone else; I simply cant give this show a higher score because the first half of it was....well bad. The show doesn't seem to do anything of real interest until the introduction of the 7 words. I feel if they would have shown this plot and the antagonist from the early episodes (after the usual introduction episodes) and then expanded on this, and in more details of say word origins, more of the world backstory such as the rest of the 9 witches etc. The story would have been vastly more captivating and heldmy attention more. Granted i have nothing against the silly episodic episodes that a lot of anime have. Its just in this case i feel it wasn't necessary from the jump.

Hello Trigger.
I see you've made another Trigger animu with the Trigger art style and the Trigger over the top style.
Wait no, you didn't. You applied your art style to a fairly generic anime story with no over the top-ness. Huh.
Well however you wanna play it.
Little Witch Academia is what happens the eternally bombastic Trigger decides to be more restrained and do a story that doesn't end up referencing Gurren Lagann so much that it ends on the intergalatical scale.
And unlike the other anime that tried that ( the forgettable Kiznaiver ), Little Witch is SURPRISINGLY VERY GOOD.
After the absolutely entertaining yet very messy and pointlessKill la Kill, who in my eyes cemented Trigger as that studio where all the visual artists go but they have nobody to write a story that actually is worth reading, and Kiznaiver who had a pretty bleh plot and story, and everything else as well I saw from them, I just expected this one-time movie to crash in the plot and characters department when turned into a full fledged double season anime.


Well LWA is good. It just is. The characterisation was far better than expected, there is actual depth that makes sense, and it is as well animated and supported by an excellent soundtrack as one might expect from Trigger. Only the plot takes this down from a 9 to an 8.


Well rather the plot and the (usual?) Trigger pacing. It seems like LWA divides itself yet again into the part that's entirely about world and character building, from episode 1 to episode 14 roughly. Around episode 14 the plot actually starts and it is...bleh. Meh.


Not terrible but it has several problems: one is that it's just generally poorly paced. Episode 14 is something like 10 episodes too late. At the end of the anime, I felt like a lot of time that should've been given to flesh out or build up some of the final battles were just missing.

Two is its very unpleasant habit of not justifying some of the characters' lack of action. Why does Ursula not say ANYTHING against Croix for so long? Being ashamed of her past history does not in any way justify her silence. Just make up a convenient lie, or at the very least ask Akko to be wary, or something. It feels like a plot that can only work because the characters are too dumb/immobile to react to obvious threats.

And three, it's just not a great plot. It has a few nice twists and things I did not expect would go down the way they did, but even that doesn't really make it any good. Just made it go from a very generic/boring plot to a boring plot with a few good twists that amuse.


Apart from the plot, LWA is just overall nice really. I don't really have a "critique" on it for once, simply because every complaint would feel like nitpicking.


Are the characters well fleshed out and developed? Yes. Is the world too? Yes. Does the story make sense? Mostly, apart from several actions or lack thereof from Ursula. Was there a thing that made me wanna stop binging this? Yes I guess, one Ursula stupid moment. But that really didn't stop me long, I still binged the whole thing in 2 days.


So I could go at length into how Lotte and Sucy are sort of abandoned in part 2 and the whole friendship gang of Akko drifts further away to the Constanze team, how the rivalry with Diana is twisted into a great friendship story but how then she feels like she should have been given more screen time(mainly because she turns into a friend late due to the aforementioned pacing problems), I could explain my slight distaste at Trigger seemingly always doing this unpleasant thing of developping the world at length in part 1, then only having an actual plot going somewhere in part 2(again, quite like KLK), I could bitch and moan about how part 1 is my favorite every time and that they would have probably succeeded better in my eyes by doing a simple feel-good anime with no plot, just world building and enjoyable character development and growth, I could bitch about Akko being adorable yet being another Naruto, a loudmouth with no talent who tries real hard but has no real ability, I could have rechecked my lessons instead of spending my entire weekend on this, and then waste more time on a review...


But eh.


LWA just doesn't summon my usual desire to poke sticks at anime things.


It is good. It would be a great 9/10 anime, same as Kill la Kill, if it had had a halfway decent plot instead of a poor one.


It offers a charming, interestingly animated, enjoyable world full of well done characters, and can be showed to children or adults(by which I mean weeaboos) with no restraints.


You should watch it if you have time to spare. Expect above average entertainment, expect above average animation, above average characters, and above average music, and if you're like me, you'll be just quaint with it and walk out of it satisfied.

At least, up to a certain point of our lives we all chase after lofty dreams. But the cruelty of life slowly saps away at our will to dream and strive to achieve them. We, for the most part, abandon them. That is what differentiates us from Kagari Atsuko aka Akko, the main heroine of Little Witch Academia.
In the world of LWA is a world of magic or to be more apt, a world where magic is declining. And yet Akko tries to attend a school for Witches. So she can fulfill her dreams of becoming like her idol, Shiney Chariot. And yet the momentshe arrives at the school, she learns that her idol is actually considered to be a hack and she herself lacks any talent for magic. And yet she presses on, with her stubborn demeanor, refusing to accept her weakness and most importantly refusing to give up. And thus she meets friends and rivals who are each attracted to her rather intriguing personality.


After the introductions LWA follows an episodic structure till the half way of its run. Each episode Akko finds herself in some zany adventure regarding magic. These episodes are often themed around her friends. After the halfway point, reality starts to hit. The actual consequences of trying to achieve ones dreams are introduced. At the same time an arch villain shows up and disrupts the joyful adventurous nature of the show and adds in intrigue. Culminating in a fantastic climax that can only called awesome.

As usual studio Trigger brings a fantastic visual style to the show. LWA looks distinct from every show that came out this year. The characters all have wonderful expressive animations. Meanwhile the action sequences can become outright insane in complexity and creativity. They even have a tendency to sneak in a few cheeky references in pretty much every major scene. The soundtrack is more focused on suiting various scenes instead of just on a specific theme. Though the classical music portion of the soundtrack is more noticeable as they are used in the Academy, where most of the story takes place in.

And at last it’s hard not to give a shout out to Diana Cavendish, the most well developed, well rounded and likable rival character since Kiryuin Satsuki. Both her and Akko’s growth throughout the story is what grounds the compelling aspect of the story.


Perhaps it isn’t too late to chase our dreams. Well even if it is, Little Witch Academia will try to persuade you otherwise. And even if you are not convinced, you’ll have a good time experiencing the attempt. It is beyond a doubt one of the best shows of the year.

A really charming and fun story about generational inspiration and achieving your potential that has some unexpected but very welcome social commentary, and also features some incredibly solid animation and voice work (Speaking in terms of the sub) with a great score that made for a show that fully delivered on the promise of the original short film and then a bit. I maybe would have liked to see some of the other students get a little more devlopment but with the length of the show I think they did as much as they could and even with that I would still say this isa great show overall and would highly recommend it to fans of magical girls, cute girls doing badass things, or inspiration stories.

Little Witch Academia:
First and foremost, this is one of the most beautifully animated and most colorful shows I've ever had the pleasure of watching. every single second of animation feels like a wonderful eye massage that leads to a happy ending. lets tackle the individual parts of this show 
The characters+story:
While the hardly original "I wanna be X" cliché has been done to death, LWA manages to have fun with the idea by having the main Protagonist, Akko be actually terrible at everything aside from the climax of an episode. She moves to Luna Nova to become a witch and despite having no magical prowessto speak of, she desires to be like her idol Shiny Chariot. surrounded by a crew composed of a girl obsessed with mushrooms and brewing, Susy, and a shy introvert named Lotte, while the show has a colorful supporting cast, they all can be summed up in one or two sentences. this is by far the weakest part of LWA the supporting cast is composed of mostly certain tropes that really don't anything creative with the idea other than "theyre witches" Akko and her rival in the series Diana are far and away the best characters in the show aside from Akkos mentor Ursula. While the show doesn't do anything wrong with its characters its doesn't do anything to push them or the cliché they are apart of further and both the story and characters earn a 6/10 \n\n
Art/Sound: this is the real meat and potatoes of the show, easily some of the best, fluid, colorful and fun animation and music Trigger has done period. if you're an art person or a visual person you will adore this show no matter what. Shiny Ray, the OP starts on a beautiful image of the shows title being carved out of magic and leads to, while not a perfect or revolutionary, very well directed OP. there is nothing else to describe the show visually other than downright gorgeous and the music accompanying it just accentuate the show more 10/10 in both without question \n\n
Enjoyment: if you love watching cute witches do cute witch things/ a highschool girl who isn't good while her peers around her succeed and her struggle to keep up with them, or just want to watch something fun and light hearted, absolutely give it a go. 10 from me. \n\n
Overall: normally I would average everything together and if I were to do that this show would get an 8. for me however, the visuals and clear passion that went in put me in a position where I feel id be doing a disservice to the show by scoring it anything less than a 10. the visuals especially are just so damn good. having rewatched this show twice and starting a third Id feel bad about giving this anything less than a 10 overall. give it a watch especially if you love the visual style trigger is known for, you will love the bright expressive colors and characters. 10

Presentation/Animation 10/10: Holy shit, have I never been so enraged reading words written about the collection of pixels I watched accompanied by audio. The myriad [I love that word] complaints about the "lackluster special effects" or "inconsistent animation" will haunt me until I die, and probably even after. Moving on to the actual reviewing. It's by far and away the best animation of 2017 and were it released in 2016 would give Mob Psycho 100 a good match. Oh wait, Mob's ugly? Oh right, since I can't use it as my 4K anime wallpaper desktop background. Right. Anyway, great soundtracks. Openings are pretty good (7/10IS NOT what should come to mind) and the difference in tone of the first/second OP is great.    


Story/Character 10/10: Why are people on this site so focused on character depth and plot complexity? Is it impossible to enjoy a simple story with a lovable cast of characters? What I love about this is that the undeniably simple characters in My Hero Academia are labeled as "charming and believable" while Little Witch Academia gets marked as "boring, predictable and 1-dimensional". The plot is NOT cliché, anyone who says this is clearly a pleb in an elitist's wolf skin pretending to only enjoy "smart" anime. Pathetic! Can you actually name another anime which follows a strikingly similar plot line? That's the definition of cliché you know. So after my tirade on MAL reviewers and how they're all objectively wrong, we move onto... continuing this rant. I mean, at least it's not as bad as the tragedy that is Hibike! Euphonium's score or Hoshi wo Ou Kodomo, but whatever. Okay NOW it's over.


MAL Reviews/Reception 0.125/10: At least people bothered to attempt using their brain to think about the show? Clearly not enough to realize basic concepts such as "wait a minute I don't have to analyze a show for 40 minutes for it to actually be good" or "am I so pretentious that every anime that features cute girls is automatically 2/10 moe slice of life trash". Actually scratch that I change my rating of the other MAL reviews to a 0.0675/10. Meticulously calculated.

One trope that anime uses time and time again is the underdog story. In which the main character is a nobody who has a dream, is told they can’t do it, but they work hard and believe and they achieve their goals. While this is a very good message to younger viewers, for anime veterans such as myself, it kind of gets old after awhile, so a show like this something special to stick out from all the rest. And Little Witch Academia delivered on that and more.
Story: 7/10 The story of Little Witch Academia follows Akko Kagari. A young girl who has a dreamof becoming a witch like her idol, Shiny Chariot. To do this, she attends the prestigious school for witches, Luna Nova. She quickly finds out, however, that it’s very tough for her to fit in there. She can’t perform magic nearly as well as everyone else and she can’t even fly on a broomstick. As such she gets bullied a lot by her classmates. Especially a snobbish girl named Diana Cavendish and her 2 friends. Despite this, Akko still believes in herself and still tries to improve as a witch. There is one major flaw with the story though. It takes forever for any major plot points to kick in. The first 10 or so episodes feel more like episodic adventures of Akko and her two friends Lotte and Sucy getting into mischief or going on a crazy adventure. It isn’t until the second half when the true plot kicks in, when Akko’s teacher Ursula tells her that she needs to find the seven words of Arcturus in order to give the Shiny Rod (a wand that was owned by Chariot and is now inherited by Akko) magic power. It is then that Akko’s adventure truly begins. While the more episodic first half is fine and very fun to watch, I feel like it didn’t need to drag on as much as it did and it caused many people I’ve talked to to drop the show early. Once the plot kicks in though, it’s truly magical (pun intended)


Art: 9/10 Studio Trigger is no stranger to unique and quirky art styles, so needless to say, this anime looks great. Obviously it isn’t animated as good as the OVA and short film, but considering this is a 24 episode TV series I can forgive that. The art is very vibrant and colorful and really sucks you into the world of this anime. Coupled with unique, standout character designs and many different locations that the characters visit, you better believe that this anime will hook you in with the art.


Sound: 8/10 The soundtrack to this anime is very fitting for a show like this. The songs sound magical and mysterious, yet upbeat and charming at the same time. Both opening songs are very upbeat and motivating songs to emphasize the “follow your dreams” message that the anime has. The voice acting is very good too. Each character has a unique standout voice that reflects their personality making each one recognizable. All in all, very little complaints with the sound.


Characters: 9/10 Little Witch Academia excels with its characters. I’ve already mentioned Akko, so let’s talk about some of her friends. Lotte is the brains of the group and is a major bookworm. Sucy is very monotone and obsessed with mushrooms, Diana is a know it all snob that is respected by everyone at the school and may or may not contribute to Akko’s life, we have Ursula who is Akko’s mentor and has a huge secret about her that I won’t dare spoil for you, and I would talk about Crois, but I don’t want to get into spoiler territory here. Some characters could have gotten a bit more screen time and development, but nothing too major. Other than that, Little Witch Academia handled its characters very well.


Enjoyment: 9/10 This show was a joy to watch every Monday back in the Winter and Spring 2017 seasons. The first half is fun to watch just to see what antics Akko and her friends will get into in each episode, and the second half is even better as we get to see Akko’s journey to find the seven words and even get a few VERY shocking reveals along the way. All in all, this anime was a joyride all the way through.


Overall: 8/10. Little Witch Academia had its share of issues such as the first half feeling more like a drag plot wise and some characters not getting enough screen time, but even then, the good definitely outweighs the bad and we get an inspirational story about following your dreams and working to improve yourself instead of trying to be like others. I highly recommend you watch this with a younger kid, as this show is appropriate for all ages (for the most part) and the message will definitely speak to a younger audience as well as an older one as well. Thank you for reading.

The reason why I started watching Little Witch Academia is quite simple to explain. I was neither especially hyped for the show, nor did I have particularly high expectations for it to be outstandingly good at all. It was just that I noticed the colorful and inviting logo of Little Witch Academia while scrolling on Netflix. This show really looked like light-hearted and uncomplicated fun to me, so I gave it a try. 
And guess what…that’s exactly what I got from the show. However, there is a lot more to say about this production what makes it so surprisingly great and memorable.
It is definitely notthe story which lifts Little Witch Academia so high above the average for me, because it is as simple as a story could possibly be: It basically depicts the journey of the lovely Atsuko „Akko“ Katsuragi (more about her later on) while she follows her biggest dream which is to become a magnificent witch just like her childhood idol Shiny Chariot.

I know, this plot is very unlikely to win an award in originality since it takes up plenty of anime cliches (energetic protagonist, talented and arrogant rival, school environment), but nevertheless does it effectively establish the setting, the characters and their motivations in a simple and relatable way.

Later on in the show, the plot even develops a bit further and reveals some interesting new characters, relationships and mysteries, but I won’t go any deeper into that.


So what is what makes Little Witch Academia so interesting? Perhaps the audio-visual site of the show?

Well, kind of, but not entirely. I mean, the animation quality is constantly high for sure and is most of the time in fluent motion and the character designs are adorable which makes the episodes very enjoyable to watch. However, the art style is not spectacular and absolutely stunning images are almost non-existent (which doesn’t mean there are no optical highlights).

The way more important thing regarding this aspect is the atmosphere that is conveyed, especially by the soundtrack which goes completely hand in hand with actions taking place. There is just this overall chilled vibe surrounding every dialogue and every piece of landscape which makes it so much fun when seeing the Akko and her friends interacting with each other.


And „Akko“ is definitely a key word in this previous sentence, because, honestly, I completely fell in love with this charming little witch and she is probably the biggest reason for me enjoying this show so much.

She might seem like your mediocre anime protagonist at first and yes, that’s what she may be, but every time she comes up with a new silly plan, I can’t help but smile and I am immediately compelled with her actions.

Akko’s innocence, honesty, temper and unbroken will to achieve her dream make her so charismatic and likable that every viewer should be able to enjoy her (often hilarious) adventures which always get her a bit closer to her beloved idol.  


So what is my verdict? And who do I think should watch Little Witch Academia?

Well, the second question is not so easy to answer since it highly depends on your expectations before starting the show. You won’t experience a complex story full of countless story twists or phenomenal character developments.

But if you are search for an extremely entertaining show with a light-hearted atmosphere in a cute setting, funny dialogues, endearing characters and a certain breathe of magic, Little Witch Academia is absolutely worth a look.

Personally, I had a lot of fun with Akko’s adventure and didn’t regret a single time commencing the show.

I came into this series as a NetFlix Selection and was pleasantly surprised by the charm of this story. I thought it would be a 'Harry Potter meets Anime' story, but was pleasantly surprised by an well-thought out original story with some great characters and fantastic narrative twists. The TV series expanded upon the OVAs with a full two season TV narrative presentation, allowing characters like sometimes rival/ sometimes friend Diana Cavendish or the brash Amanda and their respective cliques to receive more development as friends of series leads Ako, Lotte, and Sucy. A well made anime with a happy and wholesome message, it wasactually a lot happier story of young magicians than the darker Pottermore films and I found my assumption of it being cliche to be mistaken.

I have not yet watched the movies or the special episode, I started watching this series not knowing a single thing about it. I had not watched a single "Why you should watch Little witch academia" or any reviews on youtube, but I still decided to watch it because I had not heard anything bad about it either.
And I am really glad I gave it a shot, because when the first episode started rolling, I knew that this was going to be something good. The art was amazing and the animation was fluid. It somehow reminded me of Harry Potter when I first saw it.It was a feeling of nostalgia and childlike innocense. The animaton also kept on astoundingly surprise, the magic is animated so well that it is almost breathtaking. So, the animation is really good and so is the art (The art is also a little different from "normal" anime and I think that is really refreshing to see.).


The story is not the most fleshed out one, but it keeps going and the characters keep going with it. In the first few episodes that almost feel like filler, I was a little nervous -but I knew I was going to finish this series, I believed in this series to be good. The characters are very likable and it is not a show that is entirely comedy, but it is neither entirely serious. It has a tone that kind of shifts, sometimes it is pretty serious and sometimes it is all fun and games, but it does not take away anything from the fluidity of this series.


You might think me prasing this series is just the work of some fanboy, but I believe that this series is something that really made me feel something. I remembered why I started watching anime in the first place, because of the astonishing visuals, the good story, the engaging plot (the plot in this series is not really the main focus of the series though, it is more like glue that keeps the series together, but it is enjoyable nonetheless), the likable characters. Everything in this series truly opened up my heart and to be honest, I actually cried a little towards the end... 


I rated this show 10/10 because of how good this series made me feel, it is one of those series that will stick with you for the rest of your life -if you only let it. I am not an experienced anime reviewer (This is my first review ever) and I can not say I am a truly experienced anime viewer. But I decided to review this series because of how good it is and because, "Never forget, a believing heart is your magic."

Little Witch Academia... TRIGGER's latest work has many things to say about it; I mean come on this is TRIGGER we're talking about here, of course we would!
Story: 7
The story and plot wasn't bad per say, but I can say that for the first half it kinda drags on and feels a bit irrelevant to the overall show. Nevertheless there were some enjoyable parts in there (And references ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) heh.) overall the story was a bit above average.
Art: 7
This may be a bit biased but it felt like this didn't completely live up to the TRIGGER standard. Was definitely good, but notgreat you know? Again an above average score here.\n\n
Character: 8\n\n
This is mainly where the show thrived, fleshing out the characters to a certain extent and focusing on their distinct personalities. A Damn good job if I do say so myself. It was definitely interesting looking into the characters lives.\n\n
Overall: 8\n\n
Overall this was a pretty enjoyable anime, recommend as a kickback feelgood show. Bloody good job TRIGGER!

A Christian's Anime Review
Little Witch Academia
Discernment Topics
Violence: \/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Slapstick shenanigans abound.
Blasts of magic destroy the environment and magical constructs during occasional fights.
A sword fight ensues in one episode.
Some characters briefly, and somewhat comically, produce torture equipment and state their intention to use them. However, they are quickly reprimanded and foiled.
Language:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
I only heard 1 or 2 light curses.
Spiritual Content:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Witch-themed spirituality abounds. The themes, however, don't attempt to be serious and are generally in context with the shows comedic appeal.
Ghosts, spirits, and various other magical things abound.
Fanservice/Sexual Content/Nudity:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Very minor fanservice in the form of short skirts and slightly revealing stage garb.
One episode had a magical bee sting people,causing them to fall in love with the first person they saw. We briefly see some victims gazing longingly at members of the same gender. The overall tone was just another hijinx though.\n\n
Misc. Suggestive Content:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
Some people may be offended by the setting of a witch's school. However, it's clear that the form of magic in this show isn't any more demonic than Gandalf from Lord of the Rings. Nonetheless, some people can still be triggered by the word "witch".\n
The main character behaves in a disrespectful manner towards authority figures for a while.\n\n\n
Detached Assessment\n\n
Story:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
7/10\n
Individual plots remain episodic for most of the show. An overarching plot does an ok job of tying is all together.\n
Deus ex machinas abound throughout the major plot points. However, this is a Studio Trigger show after all... perhaps we should just be thankful there weren't any aliens.\n\n
Characters:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
8/10\n
Characters were all likable and fun to watch.\n
Development seems to be a little lacking for some of the characters. However, others were done quite well and had satisfying character arcs.\n\n
Art:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
9/10\n
Studio Trigger's art style has been described as stylized minimalism. I must say that they excel at this style and do not disappoint throughout the show.\n
Sakuga fights scenes... just awesome.\n\n
Sound:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
7/10\n
OPs were good, not super unique though.\n
EDs were good too. These however, were worth keeping to listen to again and again.\n
OST fit well and complemented the scenes.\n\n
Enjoyment:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
8/10\n
The pacing may not have driven the main plot forward all the time, but each episode stood on it's own virtue with their comedic value. \n\n\n
Conclusion\n
If you enjoy Trigger's brand of crazy, this will definitely appeal to you.\n
Shonen themes abound, so those fans will also find this entertaining.\n
If you have a problem with the terminology surrounding witches... then the name should have turned you off.\n
If you don't have a problem, this show is definitely worth your time if you are looking for some quality entertainment.

Little Witch Academia is a great anime. Even though it's targeted to younger audiences, I still enjoyed it at 19. It was excellent in most ways, but there were some things lacking. I didn't enjoy the story too much simply because everything was so predictable. The "twist" near the end was pretty predictable (no spoilers) and a lot of the cliches were extremely overused, and the first half of the series was just an anime port of Harry Potter. Other than that everything else was very good. Character design and backstory was pretty good especially on the main character Akko, but voice acting in theEnglish dub was lacking in my opinion. The character's voices fit their part, but they really were sort of cringey in my opinion. The original Japanese cast in my opinion was much better and more experienced. Two of the main characters in the English dub (Sucy and Ursula) were relatively new to the voice acting scene. Some might say "oh but you can be good with little experience", which is true in some cases. Sucy's voice fit her well, but that's because she was a very boring and sort of depressed character. Ursula on the other hand felt lazily done in the voice acting section even though she was a very bright and cheerful character. Overall everything was great in my opinion and I enjoyed it very much. Even though I could nitpick at some things I still find Little Witch Academia very well done and I do hope for a second season.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS. Although they are contained after a second warning below.
I am a huge fan of Studio Trigger as anyone who knows me can attest, although a recent fan to be sure. After watching Kill la Kill I heard about the LWA OVAs and immediately loved them both. 
However after following the Little Witch Academia TV series every week for six months, it's extremely difficult for me to satisfactorily summarize exactly how I feel about it. It's a very different kind of series than the first OVA, and is mostly closer both in animation and in structure to The Enchanted Parade. On theone hand, in concept and at multiple points I feel Trigger deserves extremely high praise. But on the other hand, after completing the series, a lot of of problems which I ignored while watching becaming prominent in my mind, and sometimes when I think about the series these issues dampen my enthusiasm for the series as a whole.


I will briefly summarize what I think of each of the typical MAL review criteria before going more in depth into what I feel are the greatest strengths and the greatest weaknesses - with some **SPOILERS**, because it is impossible to discuss particularly the latter without them, albeit I will try to avoid major spoilers as much as possible.


Story: The basic story on its own is extremely enjoyable. Akko's struggle to become a great witch is heartwarming and refreshing in the sense that it is wholesome without becoming cloying and you *really* want to see Akko succeed. However, as I will discuss later, the pacing issues as well as some story developments that begin around the middle of the series and reach their head in the last 5 episodes or so greatly undermine what could have been a story as incredible as anything Trigger has ever done.


Art: In terms of art style, the series is gorgeous. The backgrounds are detailed and soft in ways that are reminiscent of early Miyazaki, and the design of the locations are wonderful to behold. While the animation is clearly not as fluid most of the time as in the first OVA or even the second, at certain points, especially at the end, it rivals anything that Trigger has done. My only complaint is that some side characters' designs, particularly the characters new to the TV series, are somewhat bland and could be a lot more visually unique.


Sound: In technical terms this is probably the series' weakest point. The OPs and EDs are all great, but those are undoubtedly the high points musically. Try to do a drinking game out of how many times you hear the series' main musical motif - you'll be blacked out by the end of the series.


Character: This is the aspect of the show which I think is the hardest to score. Akko is a wonderful protagonist. I never found her annoying like she feels at times in the Enchanted Parade OVA, and in fact she and Megumi Han's performance are often what raises the quality of the episodes, as there is so much life and energy put into her character. Ursula is also very endearing as a character, even if, as I'll explain later, at the end you realize that her character is deeply flawed both in characterization and in execution.


Lotte and Sucy as always are a joy to behold - this is why in my opinion the first half of the series is in many ways stronger than the second. They are strong presences in their own right and provide a lot of depth to the first half of the series which then drops off almost ENTIRELY for the second half. Speaking of, I know Amanda, Constanze, and even Jasminka are fan-favorite characters, but they pretty much replace Sucy and Lotte in the second half of the series. Even then Amanda and Constanze get individual episodes and then don't have that much impact on the story of the second half, which is focused almost entirely on Akko.


And then there are the three characters which I have the most to say about critically - Andrew, Diana, and Croix. I'll save this for the end, but suffice it to say that I think Trigger and especially Yoshinari were extremely misguided in the way they used these characters, and considering how important they are at various points in the series, it's a major strike against the series as a whole.


Enjoyment: This is also hard to score because while watching it, aside from a couple of episodes, I was immensely entertained. However it could be argued that if anything there is way, *way* too much focus on immediate entertainment within each episode at the expense of the cohesion of the series as a whole. 


Overall: I fluctuate between a 7 when I'm ungenerous and 8 when I am generous toward this series, and at this point I will summarize what I think is the series' greatest missteps, but...


**BEWARE: SPOILERS BELOW**


It is abundantly clear that Yoh Yoshinari should, like George Lucas in many ways, stick to grander ideas and character designs rather than directing the finer points of storytelling and character development. If there is one thing that threatens to sabotage the series as a whole, it is this.


Trigger clearly was going for a Western-style animated series which balances SOL elements and struggles with an overarching story. Fantastic - this should be greatly commended, considering how this concept apparently is foreign to many anime fans yet holds a lot of potential. In fact I think the SOL episodes and the story-based episodes on their own are almost equal in quality, rather than either feeling like filler. However, the way this kind of series is usually structured in Western animation is by interweaving SOL and side character-based episodes with plot-related ones. Instead, Trigger mostly decided to put all of the SOL episodes in the first half, and then all of the main story in the second. This creates an extremely lopsided series that almost feels like two separate seasons or even two different shows rather than one. And considering the issues with the plot structure and character development which I will discuss, the problems with this approach are exacerbated if anything.


The problems with the plot structure and character development are the most clear with the way the three characters of Andrew, Diana, and Croix are handled.


Croix is not even introduced until halfway through the series, and from *literally* the very first episode we are shown that she is evil, as well as the somewhat heavy-handed theme of "technology vs. tradition." However, by the end of the series we are only somewhat more clear on why she became this way, and it seems to boil down to "I wanted to become the witch that saved magic but didn't get chosen." It seems strange that Croix essentially became evil for this reason, yet her motivations seem to be misguided at best. If her development didn't get left until the very end of the series, maybe she could have been fleshed out more.


Ursula/Chariot herself also suffers from a similar issue - despite her being a major part of the series, until episode *22* we have no idea about why she quit her performances as Shiny Chariot, and the way the show handles this character revelation is MASSIVELY bungled. The rug is pulled out from under the audience which has seen Ursula and Akko's relationship as entirely wholesome not only for the previous twenty-one episodes, but both OVAs as well, yet we get not even a FULL EPISODE to examine this enormous character development. An even bigger problem with this is that Chariot's error essentially boiled down to "I trusted Croix too much" - at one point they hint that maybe Ursula didn't care about the consequences of her magic, but it's a plot point that's immediately dropped. And by the way, try to rewatch any training scenes with Akko and Ursula and not cringe constantly at how painful it is. In hindsight so much of what Ursula does to try to help Akko feels almost condescending and mocking, and again, because this plot point is dragged out so long, it taints most of the series.



In any case, if there are two characters who are arguably more bungled than Croix and Chariot, it's Diana and Andrew.


Andrew is the one major side character introduced solely for the TV series, yet by the end I am entirely unclear what in the hell Yoshinari and Trigger were trying to do with him. An apologist might argue that he's meant to embody the non-magical world which has rejected magic, but there's two problems with that. One, the issue of Croix exploiting the emotions of the non-magical public as well as the climax of the show already handle this topic without needing Andrew. Secondly, it is abundantly clear that that is *not* all Trigger were planning on doing with him, until, again, episode 20 or so, where they shift hard AWAY from involving him in the main plot in any serious manner. We don't even get a final scene to cap off his development or have him discuss his and Akko's mutual character-building. Because due to the changes in the story, there's no time.


Also, I'm going to touch the third rail of the Little Witch Academia fandom, because it is an issue which leaks into the canon of the series and embodies some of the biggest weakeness of the TV series...


SHIPPING.


Andrew is quite clearly introduced, if not as a love interest for Akko, then as someone to whom she is able to elaborate who she is as a character. He acts as a perfect foil for her, and their relationship in my view has as lot of compelling inversions to the typical action-adventure hetero relationship. They have actual chemistry, and in the first half of the series, it seems like Andrew shows a lot of promise as a character and his relationship with Akko, whether romantic or not, had a lot of potential, which is clearly recognized by Trigger early on. 


Who is the only character in episode six who is there when Akko has one of her best character scenes, where she opens her heart about her hopes and fears in trying to be like Shiny Chariot? ANDREW. Who is there in episode 10 when again, we see Akko provide the supposed main theme of the series, that magic itself is worthwhile because it revitalizes the world and provides joy? ANDREW. And even in the second half of the series, we see repeatedly that Andrew and Akko have an extremely engaging chemistry and character interplay, and Akko as a character is at her strongest when she's able to tell Andrew exactly why she wants to keep looking for the Words.


... So where in the hell does he go at the end? I'll tell you the answer, based on interviews with Yoshinari. For some baffling reason, which if I were uncharitable I would attribute to spite, Trigger decided about halfway through the series (I would venture after episode 10) that they didn't want Andrew involved in the main plot anymore. Instead, they decided they wanted *Diana*, both as a major plot element, and as a pseudo love interest for the yuri fans to cheer for. 


I will say this. I do not like Diana. At all. She at no point becomes interesting to me as a character, or endearing. She has the chemistry of a rock with Akko, and I can probably count on one hand the number of times she shows any kind of emotion, positive or negative. It's actually interesting because the basis of her relationship with Akko, at least at first, is similar to Andrew's. But whereas Andrew from the beginning shows at least some kind of interest, if not amusement, towards Akko, and is able to engage with Akko, Diana does no such thing. Her character interactions with Akko for 90% of the series boil down to the typical "tsun" relationship. Boy, that's sure original. There are a couple of amusing moments where Akko almost gets an emotional rise out of Diana, but it never actually happens. Akko just at some point decides she admires Diana enough that she wants to get involved in her side plot.
