By the way, speaking of Andrew, when he is introduced and it's mentioned that Andrew and Diana have known each other since childhood, and considering Andrew and his father are somewhat tied into Diana's "side plot," I think there is a grand total of ONE conversation between Diana and Andrew as well in the whole series. His contribution to her story is the equivalent of a backstory dump.


But in any case, Diana as a character starts as the stereotype of a school snob and teacher's pet, and at the very least through the first half of the series, is basically a Mary Sue. I know that term is frowned upon, but she is the definition of it. The absolute worst of this is episode five, where she literally comes OUT OF NOWHERE, reveals that unlike any of her own teachers she has taught herself Draconic language and contract law, apparently, and resolves the main conflict of the episode immediately. This is basically how she is involved in the first 13 or so episodes as well - she just shows up to either be condescending to Akko (only to be shown up by Akko in some regard) or just show off how much smarter than everyone else she is.


And yet, she more or less disappears from the main action of the plot until THE LAST FIVE EPISODES, where suddenly we are given a *two-part story* about Diana, and now she is arguably the second most important character. This would be fine to some degree if it were used to make Diana interesting or compelling as a character, but no, it's just to show how special and hard-working Diana is, which is indirectly a huge slap in the face to Akko as well, since despite working for probably close to a year on her magic, she at best can transform herself into a few animals. It feels as if Yoshinari just decided that because he liked Diana for whatever reason, she needed to be inserted into the main plot, but without having a good story or character reason.


And then in the final two episodes we are essentially given a heaping spoonful of yuribait, despite Akko and Diana STILL having less than zero chemistry. Diana almost even upstages Akko *at the finale*, and it takes away from Akko's big moment to shine. It left a really bad taste in my mouth, particularly after hearing the crowing from certain elements of the fandom that their yuri ship was now "canon" - not that it technically is, as much as Yoshinari and apparently Megumi Han according to other interviews clearly want it to be.



So bottom line, regardless of opinions on various shipping pairs or what have you, these issues of character development and pacing could have been resolved if they were planned out before the series aired. Instead it feels like Yoshinari and Trigger were changing things as they went along, and it threatens to completely derail the series. And it's a crying shame because this series could have been Trigger's absolute best - yes, perhaps even better than Kill la Kill. Instead we have an extremely enjoyable but deeply flawed series which at points feels more like Kiznaiver than the Little Witch Academia OVAs or any other work Trigger has done.

First amateur review: im avoiding making spoilers as much as i can.
At first we had those OVAs. now we have a series that started without much impact. but each week of a new release. i didn't realize how enchanting this anime is! at first i was having thoughts like. "yeah its pretty decent. 2017 is starting off good". after watching more episodes. I CANT STOP THE ADVENTURE. 
Little Witch Academia gives a smooth ride from start to finish. with a little twist on the end. it takes you back and change all that you knew. leaving you thinking about the past. even then they gavea blossoming ending that left me a smile.


Story(8/10): Started to go into the school yada yada. pacing will be a bit slow for others who wants a linear and always moving story. here we have lots of side stories. the everyday life of our hero akko. and her adventures with her friends.


Art(9/10): Its art is good. well animated. and is definitely above average from the usual. most movements looked fluid and the colors and character design are well above average.


Sound(9/10): just good. everything fits well. the atmosphere is handled well by the BG sound. each orchestra pieces are flexible enough and is used accordingly when needed. from the energy lifting piece shifts to a more of an action and thrilling piece.


Character(9/10): Now this is one of the highlights of the show. the certain chemistry of characters hanging out together and by being with each other. but the friendship of the trio is what i loved the most. Characters had good development. and development is majorly caused by our main Akko. and how she drives everyone and me to have a "believe it" moments at most times.


Enjoyment(10/10): I've enjoyed it. from when we started and when we finished. it felt watching everyone grow and learn from each other. by being together and staying strong when all hope is lost. we must never forget. a believing heart is your magic.

Little Witch Academia is the "Savior of Anime", for the Winter 2017 season that is. What we got that season was a decent yet half-hearted attempt to re-tell WWII in an alternate setting with the influence of magic (see Youjo Senki) and a figure skating anime riddled with too many flaws to count (still won Crunchyroll Anime of the Year award) *cough*cough* The show overall was a spectacle to witness in its own way. I mean that the show had its own charm that came off well (utsukushii and kawaii characters and their relationships, and the picturesque setting, magic boarding school Luna Nova). Granted StudioTrigger did test the waters in the first 9 episodes or so to gauge the direction they might take the show and the viewer reception to said storyline experimenting. Some of the episodes in the first nine came off way too shounen-like, almost in the unbearable Pokémon shounen fashion; the episode where Akko was strolling around Sucy's dream world to help "free her mind" (i.e. wake up) was especially jarring. Starting from episode 10, I could definitely see Trigger getting its act together as they started making great use of their cast, giving them depth, and building up each episode to make a cohesive story. The ending was solid and borderline amazing for a shounen in Winter 2017. So, of all the Winter 2017 anime, this one is etched in my mind as THAT anime I recommend should someone ask, "Anything good from Winter 2017?"

Story - Basically the story is about a young teen girl named Atusko that is in a time of where magic is in decline and looked down upon she is trying her best to become the greatest witch she can by trying to follow through the footsteps of her idol and along the way of learning and making mistakes she makes her own path to becoming that.
charterers - there are four main charterers Atsuko Kagan, Sucy Manbavaran,Lotte Yansson, and Diana Cavendish, as for backstory there's very little in various episodes where you find something through words and such not much of them showing there backstories from what we know Atsuko is from a non magic family and got into the school due to a low budget, Sucy's background is a bit cloudy but we know she's dark and loves to collect deadly things poisons, mushrooms, and varies other potion ingredients, as for her experiments and such, Lotte is like your generic glasses character she has deep feelings and loves to read She also comes from a magic family that owns a magic shop cafe, Diana, is a top student and the rival of Atusko she also comes from a high-class magic family.


Animation- the animation its self keeps the anime refreshing and feels lively throughout every episode it makes you feel very warm inside and other times a bit dark only because it's got a dip of cuteness inside that keeps it from being so, the animation truly makes this magic anime stand out for sure and will keep you watching even if it gets a bit dry in some episodes.


Voice acting - honestly the sub seems to be the best fit it makes the cute world fit altogether better than the dub, and the dub sounds more like a cartoon as to a true anime to me if I didn't know better I would think this is something off of cartoon network but still varies person to person.


Music/sound effects - the music used in all the episodes are very magic themed and very well fitting where ever they put it in, the theme is so cute like this shows animation as for the sound effects they are truly great and make everything more lively from the wind when they are on their broomsticks to the sound of there magic wands waving to make spells.


The rating -  rating this is really hard basically from everything seen in the story it feels very generic but the way they did the episodes makes it feel better every episode is like it's own little short with a couple glimpses at that true story there trying to tell along the way a lot of the time the anime can lose its cuteness and feel like it's on repeat but when the music and actors come out it's really good but what really makes it stand out is the great animation they decided to use it really turns this thing into a true beauty and makes it stand out by far and makes up for the non creativeness used in this anime i truly feel like this is a 7/10 even though it's just the story line that comes out as the biggest mistake but what really bugs me is we don't get to see a lot from the little to none backstory we want to know more about before all four got into the school and how being a witch really affected them as a child but still it's not too late for that as for season two starts in October. 



p.s this is my first review on here and I hope to do more in the future I hope it helps you to choose the right anime to watch

This anime brought a 20 year old into a series of magical journey she thought she would be too old to enjoy.
The story had a really good start, and the anime was able to keep it up. It started with Akko who dreams of becoming a magical witch who is able to bring smile to everyone's faces, like her idol - Shiny Chariot. However, upon reaching Luna Nova, she finds out that trying to become a witch is very hard. She can't even fly. 
And we all thought that was it. And then it got deeper and deeper and it got more enjoyable. The journeytook us into Akko trying to make the world a better place, doing the unexpectable, though she is only equipped with her believing heart. She does not have the ability, nor the magic talent, but she pushed her way through. You would be tricked into thinking "wow she has a slow character progression", but there is actually something behind it which I really loved. 


The art and animation was outstanding. You could really feel the action scenes from behind the screen. They were able to make it incredibly magical, true to its purpose of making the viewers a part of the journey. Everything will make you wish you would have lived in that kind of world.


The characters are lovable no matter who they are. The friendships built, the progression from the very start, is really good. Even the villain is very much understandable.


I enjoyed this anime all throughout. It was really great, and it gave off some CCS feels which I long for nowadays. We lack animes like this. Beautiful start, and a beautiful ending. Just, beautiful. This is really worth the watch. The kid in me awakened, and hoped that I never grew old.

È l'anime che ha salvato l'animazione. Punto. Nient'altro da dire. È tutto fottutamente spettacolare. I personaggi son caratterizzati benissimo, anche se alcuni un po' stereotipati. Akko è la classica capra fannullona incapace e testarda, ma la si vuole sempre bene è impossibile da odiare. Diana è il miglior personaggio. Punto. Non ha bisogno di nessun'altra spiegazione. È fottutamente perfetta. Ursula/Chariot gestita benissimo, waifu al punto giusto è uno dei miglio personaggi. Ryuko Mat... ehm Amanda. Si lei... Sinceramente la presenza di un personaggi che ricordasse sia nell'aspetto che nel carattere Ryuko mi è piaciuto tantissimo (Ryuko per me è la vita). È stata una bellissimaautocitazione da parte della Trigger. Croix la classica antagoniste, che fa cose malvage a fin di bene, che poi si pente. Mi è piaciuta molto anche lei. Andrew invece non si deve azzardare a toccare Akko. Akko è di Diana. A parte  le stronzate, Andrew è il personaggio scettico che poi passa al "lato oscuro". Ovvero l'unico con un po' di sale in zucca in mezzo a quei cretini contro la magia. Sucy, Lotte, Costance ecc. tutti buoni personaggi. Bellissima la citazione a TTGL, veramente spettacolare, come del resto tutte le piccole chicche nascoste qua e la. Poi. L'episodio 25... l'episodio 25 è un epifania di avvenimenti, gestiti maestosamente. È l'anime dall'anno.\n
CHAPEU STUDIO TRIGGER!\n
(Fate la stagione 2 pls, senza Akko non posso stare :(   )

A fun anime that could go well with younger audiences but successfully brings warm feelings of hope and wonder to even older viewers like myself.  I've never actually written a review for an anime before, but I felt compelled to write a review of this amazing and unique series and encourage others to watch Little Witch Academia (LWA).
Let's start with the individual aspects:
Story - 9/10
The overall plot of the story is rather simplistic, especially in the beginning - a young witch who struggles to realize her dream of being like her idol, and who despite her weaknesses somehow manages to shine and do thingsthat others couldn't.  Indeed the producers don't make much of an effort to hide their foreshadowing and many parts of the story are quite predictable, but the story writers manage to make each episode an exciting, fun, and adventurous story on their own.  True, each episode doesn't pack as much plot as a single OVA (after all, an OVA is relatively short compared to a 25 episode series) but this enabled the story to progress at a comfortable pace and to develop the characters and the plot in a more nuanced fashion.  For the uncanny way LWA manages to turn a simple plot into something exciting, while interweaving themes about pursuing one's dream, friendship, and change, I give this series a 9.


Art - 10/10

Full disclaimer - I'm in love with Studio Trigger's artwork.  Kill La Kill was the first work I had seen by this studio and above anything, it was the artwork that had captivated me.  LWA continues to uphold the high standard set by Trigger's previous works.  Their ability to capture action through different contrasts, to capture a variety of nuanced facial expressions (and combine it with superb voice acting) is simply mesmerizing.  The artwork does an excellent job of setting the mood and air for the story, with dark scenes that evoke feelings of mystery punctuated with the green sparkles of magic that evoke awe and wonder. I could go on with examples from the series, but it'll probably be best to see the series for yourself.


Sound - 8/10

The openings/endings were pretty awesome, though not particularly noteworthy, in my opinion.  I really liked the first and second openings.  The first seemed to evoke feelings of hope, childish naivete, and magical wonder, while the second seemed more serious, and mature (but maybe it's just me).  For it being good but not outstanding, I give the sound an 8.


Character - 9/10

The characters in LWA were amazing.  Trigger does an excellent job of giving each main character a very distinct personality, even right from the first episode.  This is accomplished through excellent artwork that captures the personality of each character through their character design, color pallet, facial expressions, right down to their movements, and the superb voice acting.  Character development was especially amazing - I don't want to give any spoilers, but one particular character's development is particular striking - she is given far more development in the TV series and becomes a completely different character than we would have ever expected from the original OVAs.  That's all I'll say.


Enjoyment - 10/10

It comes as no surprise that I absolutely enjoyed (and adore) LWA.  The execution of the ideas is simply amazing, and every episode is its own adventure and packed with hilarious jokes, references, and humor.


Overall - 10/10

It's rare that something like LWA, a simple story involving young schoolgirl witches (who sorta save the world, but not really) could turn into something so amazing and enjoyable.  The art and acting work together so well to give amazing characters and a fun, exciting plot.  I definitely recommend people to watch LWA, and even if the beginning seems a bit slow at first, realize that it's all setup for more interesting developments that happen later on.  Proof that even a more lighthearted story about young characters in school can be a true masterpiece.

Despite some negative comments some people have wrote about this series, I'd like to critique it with praise.
Story: 8
This anime's story starts off kind of slow. It starts off with a young girl, Akko with big dreams and very (and by "very", I mean abysmally) low levels of talent for accomplishing her dream - which is to become a prominent witch that can bring big smiles to those watching her perform her magic. Now, this set up would have very little substance if not for the world building that happens around her dreams and perceptions of the magic world of witches. Namely, I'm referring tothe fact that most actual witches regard the idea of using magic to entertain others as low class and not worth while. Despite starting off with cringe-worthy levels of ability and general lack of popularity, however, Akko, becomes a heroine that shines and wins the hearts of both in-story characters and audience viewers alike; her journey in this tale warms hearts, and her determination gets others to cheer her on. In addition, even though the first half of the series didn't really seem to have much of a villain, the plot ties itself together from beginning to end and by the end, you realize all those more-or-less casual events that seemingly didn't connect with the villain's build up actually matter and lead to her success at the end.


Character: 9

If I had to say whether this is an anime that is plot-driven, character-driven, art-driven or music-driven, I'd say this is a character-driven work. Akko, the main character grows tremendously by the end and it's her journey that make this show great. However, just like she couldn't have accomplished what she did at the end alone, this show would not have been so great if it was just her development. Everybody besides Akko, from Lotte and Sucy, Diana and Andrew, her teachers Ursula and Croix, and even minor characters like Amanda and Constanze, all get an episode or two dedicated to their development at some point in the story. Heck, even Diana's Cinderella-esque aunt and cousins exhibit some change or growth. As a result, the characters, even if minor, feel very real and dynamic. The world of Little Witch Academia comes to life because of this.


Art: 8

Okay, let's be real. This isn't a stunning backgrounds with vivid and detailed character models show. But that in no way makes it bad. The artstyle, in fact, help to exaggerate the facial expressions and really bring out the character's reactions. It's also suitable for the overall not-so-emo-and-pretentious mood of the anime. Some shows like Fate/Zero may deserve more serious styles of animation but with this one, the kind-of goofy artstyle and almost disney-esque expressions just fit very well.


Sound: 7

Sadly, this is the weakest aspect of the show. It's mostly because there was nothing that really stood out on it's own. There are shows out there that are almost purely song-driven, like Macross Delta, but this isn't one of them. The opening and ending themes adequately reflect the tone and mood of the story, but in no way do more than that. That said, it's not bad either.


Enjoyment: 9

I started this off skeptical since the synopsis made me wonder if it was going to be like Harry Potter, which, if it were, it would have made me drop the show. It slowly became one of entries I looked forward to most every week as the show aired. There were moments where I just cracked up at Akko's antics. Other moments where I got interested in the backstory of other characters. In general, this show made me feel good every week. It also drives home a point that I can attest is important to every kid or teenager, or even an adult who is having a hard time in life - "A believing heart is magic". It's message is clear - believe in your abilities and potential and work towards it and it will be the "magic" that will make you succeed in life.


Who's this show for?

-People who can enjoy a series with a positive message

-People who want a feel-good story

-People who like magical stories

-School genre fans


Who's this not for?

-If you wanted emotional drama

-If you wanted something more...serious. 

-If you were here for moe, tsundere, or some other cutesy anime trope. Sorry, this one kind of don't have your typical character tropes.

STORY: It's the life of an underdog that wishes to take on the same footsteps as her idol (Shiny Chariot). Taking part of new adventures at school and beyond is the fun part. Akko gets to meet new friends and struggles with her weaknesses of magic along the way. Part of it makes this anime worth watching.
CHARACTERS: 
Akko: Determined, passionate, but also clumsy, reckless and down right weird. As I mentioned previously, she is the underdog (since magic is not her strongest forte -- ironically). But she never backs down from a challenge. She is also very caring to her friends.
OVERALL: One of my topfavourite animes to watch! I absolutely recommend it to everyone! Believing is key and helps us to become stronger. Plus, there is plot and character development (which is refreshing... due to the fact that a lot of animes that I've been watching are lacking lately). Personally, I can relate to Akko and her struggles. Plus, get ready to see a lot of references. These are the factors that makes Little Witch Academia worth watching ♥

The anime with zero fan service are the kind where you know the author and production studio really care about the characters and the plot. A romance does not define the story in which a female is the main protagonist but instead it is a story of friendship and comradery where people who didn't understand each other in the past come together and learn about each other and end up saving the day by believing in themselves and each other, Akko's ignorance towards who her senpai really is may be a little be cheesy but it's Akko Kagiri's innocence that adds to this stories melodramaticand melancholy dynamic that makes me feel like a kid again watching cartoons on a saturday morning without a responsibility in the world with impossible dreams manifesting in my head about how I want my future to end up. A story about a main character in a world of magic that isn't even able to ride a broom. It is a relatable story where the protagonist has a dream to become a great witch even though she is below proficient for her age on her abilities to control and utilize magic just like how some of us have dreams to be the best in a field even though we were below proficient for our age to ever hope to accomplish such a feat. Akko never gives up and with her group of friends they use the power of friendship to overcome all the odds and make not only their school a better place, but also the world they live in.

This series really grew on me. The characters, the art, the music—I started watching with low expectations.  
Akko annoyed me at certain points, but by the end I've grown to love her as a character. You've got to admire her tenacity and how she remains true to herself. I liked the progression, how what she learned on previous episodes are reflected on the new ones (except maybe the patience episode lol). I love watching her strive and work hard to be better at something, even when others say otherwise.
Sucy, Lotte, Diana, and the whole gang were awesome, and they made the series so vibrantand fun.\n\n
Overall, Little Witch Academia wasn't perfect, and some of the other episodes I thought seemed to focus on other characters than plot progression, but I truly enjoyed this series.  In its own, quirky way, it's earned its way to being one of my favourites.

This is easily Trigger's best work
Since Gueren Lagann Trigger has been focusing on remaining extremely archetypal stories through their own lens. LWA is by far the best overall product from that philosophy.
As much as I love shows like KLK and GL both had story and progression issues, KLK didn't have great pacing, and really dragged on with it's main premise. That's not to say I dislike any of these shows. This coincides with other issues i have with both series'. However after watching LWA ep 1-24 in basically 1 shot, this is the best overall product that Trigger has produced.
Like Previous trigger works, the storiesare very basic and archetypal but are re-imagined in an extraordinary matter. The evolution of animation itself may play a role in this bu LWA is by far the most intuitive and creatively made spin on such a typical and well known story. What brings this out in comparison to Trigger's other works is that the pacing is EXTRAORDINARY, every episode feels fresh and unique, even in an arc each episode is able to grab my attention easily and drag me along through the end. There is no down time in this show, and parts didn't slog nor went by too fast either it was just right. LWA may not have the super over symbolism injected into it like previous trigger works (however since the series is fresh taht would be an extremely premature statement to make) or not, only  time can tell.


Another great improvement is the ART. Trigger has not changed, they produce great quality animation and the show looks great. The improvement here is how creative it was. How LWA animators would splice in cool props and effects (all hand drawn btw) in just casual conversation or a hyped up scene. So many great shots done in the wackiest ways possible. Which made the show so enticing to watch. Trigger animators clearly love their craft so many references and nods to scifi felt like  seeing Daicon IV for the first time. Of course LWA is not daicon, but you can feel the same passion emanating from it with so many scenes.


Every character may not be Eureka Seven Tier, or Shakespearian, or the apex of writing. But every single character in LWA looks, and feels unique. The animators did a really good job making each character (even the extras) pop out. A very diverse cast that were very pleasing to watch. I won't talk about the mechanics of "character development" or "Show, don't tell" like a entitled loser. But all I can say is that I think ,you will derive enjoyment out of them, and appreciate them for their unique personalities and fun designs.


Sound is also great, Im not too big on OPs and EDs I usually skip them if they don't catch my attention easily. But some parts did have a very E7 feel to them, with that mix of adventure and adversity. It's not ground breaking but it suits the show very well. I don't think I would download it, but for the moment while watching it works wonders.


This was a very enjoyable experience for me. It greatly pleases me that studios like trigger still exist and producing this kind of content. And when my next pay comes, I hope to find a way to support it in the future. I cant really make use of the BDs but I hope to perhaps get the art book for this thats for sure. Trigger really outdid themselves here and I hope it pays off for them financially. Because quite frankly, this show is definitely worth your time, even if you are not into the content, it's quality surpasses it's thematic predispositions.

Short and sweet review. Do you know what to expect from these types of anime and are tired of people pointing out the "genre stereotypes" and then judging the anime just on that? Just want to know if you should watch it? I've got you covered.
So Little Witch Academia is one of those special anime where you are already familiar with the genre, you know what to expect, and they hit every one of the marks you KNOW they are going to hit... except it tricks your brain into thinking you're watching it for the first time because it's put together so well and isso much fun. And then they surprise you with the feels.


I don't quite know what it is about this show. But the animation looks and feels perfect, and the characters are just the right mix of hilarious and emotionally stirring, and the music hits just the right notes at just the right times when something just the right amount of epic is happening, with just the right amount of plot development in every episode. This all coalesces into an amazingly fun and moving anime that just about anyone can enjoy. Especially those who've enjoyed Harry Potter, kids and adults alike will eat this show up. It's got just the right amount of humor, feels, and adventure all surrounding a magical school core narrative. But it doesn't feel tired or annoying.


I couldn't get enough of this show when it was originally airing. I always wanted the next episode. So much fun, and just hits all the right spots for me.


HIGHLIGHTS: Just downright fun. Everything comes together to make a surprisingly good anime. A great example of the genre, fun for all ages. "Anime Girl Harry Potter".


DISAPPOINTMENTS: No more seasons planned

A believing heart is your magic, that sentence is where this whole story started. A story of a normal girl who knows nothing at all about magic enrolled into a magic academy, because she admires one great wizard named Shiny Chariot. This anime will take you into a magical adventure that will make you realize that magic is not just all about spell and wand. This anime made by trigger with their usual unique art style that made this anime even more magical. For you Harry Potter fans out there who also likes anime you will like this anime, the concept is almost the samefor the magic academy part (they don't separate houses like hogwarts thou), but the plot is completely different. I will also recommend this anime for those who just started watching anime, little witch academia should be in one of your watch list, it will give you a nice experience watching it. And don't ever forget, a believing heart is your magic!

Little Witch Academia is an anime that caught my attention due to watching the short movies that preceded it. If you've seen those short films, you've got a pretty good idea what most of the episodes are like. The general plot is pretty generic and predictable, but with a lot of interesting little hooks and twists that did a great job to improve the story. Artistically it's absolutely gorgeous. I'm not a good judge of sound, but it was pretty solid. The characters are mostly pretty standard fare for anime, but like with the story, there's enough twists and character building that they become farmore interesting than I had initially expected. Plus for there's plenty of choices for "best girl" in the series for viewers that look for that sort of thing, though it is definitely NOT a series that relies on any sort of sex appeal. It's a very enjoyable series and I think that almost any fan of anime could walk away after watching it and have had a very positive experience.

First of all the series does not continue from the first two films, it retells them and expands, adding extra scenes between events already seen in the movies to build up the world and characters and hopefully go beyond the ending of Parade, the second movie. Considering the films had to condense a lot the series allows more freedom to explore and not rush us, the audience, through things. It builds up the relationships/friendships more, like seeing how Akko, Sucy and Lotte meet and how Akko got into the Academy and her background (ie: why she sucks at magic: she's not a born witch, unlikeall the others while the movies make seem like she just is a bit behind in development)


*Character

All the characters are still the same with Akko being our guide/eyes into the world of LWA. We actually see more development from each of the main girls including Diana, the rival. We see the build up of friendship outside of the school rather than "this is a group of friends" as introduced in the movies. Each girl still has her distinct personality and talents, which are explored more. Character development is always a good thing, especially relationships. Even the girls, Amanda and the other two, who first only appeared in the second movie (who apparently been around since the first but went unseen), are seen prominently in the series in the background as well as active roles, building up their relationship with the main trio unlike suddenly being introduced in the second movie.


~Akko: A Japanese girl who saw the witch performer Shiny Chariot when she was younger and wishes to be a witch like her idol. However she comes from a non-witch lineage which puts her at a disadvantage since she doesn't know the fundamentals witches learn growing up and her magic potential sometimes comes out in spurts. She does not give up easily and is a bit of a chatter box who hates being looked down upon and is excited to learn magic, not studying.

~Sucy: A witch who hails from an implied Filipino background who is a lover of all things poisonous. She can come across as creepy and a bit obsessive when it comes to her noxious brews and research. At first she was off put by Akko's chattiness but since they're roommates she learns to tune her out or humor her or even use her as her test subject.

~Lotte: A young witch who's been attending the Academy longer than her two roommates. Rather patient, studious and well meaning, Lotte is supportive of her friends even if Akko can get into some trouble.

~Diana: An esteemed witch from a long line of witches who is the top student in knowledge and magic practice. She can be a bit of a refined show off, though not like the movie-version of herself who is a bit more snooty and direct rival to Akko through her dismissiveness. We see more dimension to her in the series. However she is willing to put her haughtiness aside for the good of all as she means well to be true to magic and its knowledge. She is poised and mostly gives facts bluntly without personal attack while her groupies do the sassing for her but Diana is honest and not excessive; when she realizes she was wrong about Akko and the Rod not being a fake, she tries to tell what happened but everyone believes that Diana the prodigy is the only one who could worked such great magic. There is obvious 'redemption' to her character in how she acts, as she is simply trying to do her best to make her family proud with the best of her abilities by going above and beyond, but the main cast think she's prideful, snooty and overly worshiped.


*Story

The story starts off with the beginning of the first movie and then moves to events that took place before Akko enrolled at the school or rather was TRYING to, to past the entry ceremony involving events seen in the movies as well as new ones due to some change in events. It starts off with Akko entering as a freshman for first term while Lotte has already been attending for a while, and Sucy enters the same time as Akko. As with the movies it shows for Akko to discover the power she has inside herself and to not stop believing and trying to do her best. Teamwork with her friends is also emphasized through the trials of life as a witch and a student between trying to master spells and encountering actual challenges and dangers. Humor and drama balances the flow of the episodes nicely. It also ties Akko's connection with Shiny Chariot much more, namely the Shiny Rod which in the movie was mysteriously at school despite Chariot's apparent disgrace as a true witch and being only an entertainer yet being the owner the powerful staff. It also establishes the fact the story takes place in our world, Akko being from Japan and Sucy implied being from the Philippines (her broom type and her last name). The tv series might reveal what happened to Chariot and where she is now, as she disappeared 10 years ago and Akko discovers her Rod in a forest. The main focus is Akko's adventures trying to learn magic and her mishaps and adventures at school and out of school, but also her goal to find Chariot and be a witch just like her.


*Art

The art style and quality is the same as the two movies. There is more showcasing of the world and magic that is in LWA. The creature designs are still memorable and fitting to the art style and the girls are still distinctive in their personal wear as well their school uniforms. The environments are rather enjoyable from the town, to leyline tower to forest to the school and more. Very enjoyable.


*Enjoyment

The tv series looks promising so far. The feel from the first two movies is not missed at all, it feels natural and well tied in with the expansion from events already seen in the movies. The new scenes are well done, including the diverting from the original film though it might get back to that point sometime via new connecting scenes (how the Rod ended up in the tower in the movie or is Akko going to hold onto it for the whole series, hence some change in events?) More development of characters, more exploration of the world, more Little Witch Academia's art, characters, and story for everyone! Watching the first episode alone is worth it if you've already seen the movies, but there are more adventures to be had!

As a fan of the original OVA and the Feature Film, I was psyched to finally get to watch the full 25 episode television series.
I can say positively that it has a strong, emotionally satisfying finish that brought me to tears.
However, I cannot give it a perfect score because the series has pacing issues early on and it takes awhile to hit its stride.  A lot of the first half is quite slog to get through, and I found myself missing the experience of the original OVA and movie quite a lot in the early episodes.  Also, while I love Akko's friend Sucyin the OVA and movie, in the TV series, while she is fleshed out more as a character, I had to admit that Sucy is kind of an asshole.  Whereas in the OVA she was merely dry, quirky and sarcastic, in the TV series she's got a sadistic edge to her that's not pretty and she warms to Akko only very slowly.  It took me awhile to warm up to Sucy myself.


Akko's building of relationships with the other girls at Luna Nova beyond her roommates Lotte and Sucy make up a large part of the middle and final acts of the TV series and are very emotionally gratifying....especially her relationship with the at first icy and aloof Diana Cavendish and the decidedly anti-social Constanze.


But most rewarding of all is Akko's relationship with Professor Ursula who is her mentor and friend.  The series also gives us the answers to what happened to Shining Chariot the performing witch and why she ended her career; this mystery is merely hinted at in the OVA and movie but addressed squarely in the final acts here.


The series definitely picks up in the latter half and becomes a thrilling ride to the end and recaptures some of the original magic of the pilot OVA and subsequent Feature Film.

Spoiler Free, also I had this readied after the finale but only posted recently. 
Honestly what do I have to say about this show, It's an Original Video Animation (or OVA for short) that was made for a government art project, that was blown up due to its charm and appeal.
Now the community always had, and still will have mixed opinions about OVA Sequel, and I personally felt that mentioned Sequel was definitely out of touch with the first OVA.
However, for the TV Series, I would have to say my opinions turned into, an acquired taste. If there's one way I can describe the TVseries, is that, it's a passion project. Creative Minds brought together by shared, as well as varying, interests and ideas. You can say whatever you will with, wonky character building, inconsistent themes (ehem, Croix Chariot Star Wars fight) and very weird pacing, but I think this just proves how much the people who created it, from Director Yoshinari sensei, Animators, and Seiyuus, had so much fun into putting their time, effort and underpayed hours into something so massively inspiring, enjoyable and heartwarming.


What the OVA didn't do that the show did Right is to bring these weird, mashed up inconsistent ideas ranging from jokes about Pie and Tarts to massive cool robots all the way to straight up nuclear warfare, and then tie them to the core idea of what made the first LWA so likable, and that is it's message of "Believing in yourself" and just overall optimistic views in life. The TV Series was able to deliver that sense of down to earth optimism despite the out of this world creations of the creators' imaginations, bringing you back to your childhood days, where you can think of absolutely anything, as long as it involved bad guys and heroes, and just dive into your imagination and never leave this perfect beautiful world you've created in your mind, where every time goes wrong, you can make it all right, as long as you believe.


This leads people to conclude that this Finale was Cheesy, Cliche and overall nonsensical, but this product of childlike wonder and imagination, is what makes you feel connected to these characters. These characters that you can honestly relate to, because once in your life, you were in a position, 

like theirs even if it was all in your head.


Because it doesn't matter if it was a cliche, believe in yourself and winner wins all, because you can look back to your days as a child and see how in your world, and in the world of Little Witch Academia, you CAN be the hero, and you CAN save the world, all you have to do is believe,


Because a Believing Heart, is YOUR magic.

To all those who want to know what anime's salvation looks like.
This is it. This is what it looks like.
A heartfelt, sincere, well thought out, simple (yet still an) emotional roller-coaster of a story.
Without any of the vices of all common anime tropes.
If you like any story (not just in anime) with great, well thought out characters, world building, prose, narrative, heart! (e.g FMA, Baccano, Harry Potter). Well, enjoy.
No need to verbose here. Just watch it.
It does not define what an anime Can be. But (imho) what it Should be.
*It may seem episodic but it's not*
*Just extending this review because of MAL, no need toread necessarily, go watch the show. (And do share your experience)*\n\n
P.S Harry Potter, not because of 'magic'. But similar vibe in storytelling and characters.\n
...And I need to prolong this review further for some reason?\n
I mean \n
Do I need to mention the ThunderCats reference in episode 17? Or the Mobile Suite Gundam/Gurren Lagann reference in episode 18?\n
It's not the reference that's important. It's the way that it's pulled off, never blatant but a narratively, stylistically and aesthetically a part of the story. A nod to fans who have watched the original and a simple sakuga moment for those who haven't.\n\n
Seriously, these references are not what make the anime. It is objectively good. Because it objectively seeks to be just a good story.\n
And a good story it is, if not great.\n
Great moral messages, and the sincerity of its characters propel it skywards.\n
(And oh hell, the first few seconds of the eds of this anime are brilliant)

This review was written by someone who finished the anime so it might contain  spoilers for some of you!
_________________________________________________________________
The first season is really good, but when it comes to the second one I cant say the same, the mix of magic and technology is so out of place, the monsters created by croix are very bad in the show's context, it ends up that the final threat was created by one of the main characters that just turns sides with no consequences at all and they just throw some of the magic concepts that were built during the anime away. If they just ignoredtech magic and continued with what was happening b4 all that, it would be way more cool, but it is still worth to watch because of the first season

"Your belief in yourself is your magic!" - Charlotte, not Kamina
Having started off as a training project for new animators, Little Witch Academia, the TV series, has blossomed into one of the best shows I've seen. Based on the title and poster, you might think it's a shoujo or some "cute girls doing cute thing" type of show, but that couldn't be further from the truth. The show is Trigger at its best, and captures everything people love about the studio. The familiar over-the-top action scenes, eccentric characters, and a plot that culminates to a dramatic finish are all elements we see in LWA. Thedifference is this time they've somehow managed to include all that without making it a strictly shounen show; it's difficult to put LWA into a specific genre. 


For this type of show, that's a good thing. What we get is an extremely well-developed story with minimal tropes. Instead, each character has a chance to shine as their own personality, and the show never makes the mistake of focusing too much on one character and allowing the others to fall flat. Each character pleasantly progresses and grows from their experiences; they are surprisingly human-like and relatable despite still having anime-like, eccentric personalities. 


The story has no fillers; each episode reveals something important about the characters or story. It is excellently paced, though I do think the ending is slightly rushed, but the episodes leading up to are well-timed and properly portrayed. Similar to other Trigger shows, the beginning of the show consists of minor conflicts with no clear obstacle for the main character to overcome. However, the later episodes require the main character to prevail over some monumental villain or task. 


LWA is an incredibly good show; its style and narrative remind me a lot of Gurren Lagann, as the quote in the beginning might have reminded you of as well. I have heard some people say this show doesn't interest them because it's just "cute girls doing cute things," but that's a wildly inaccurate statement. Like TTGL, it's a coming of age story where self-confidence is the key to your success. Therefore, any shounen or TTGL or fantasy or really any kind of fan should definitely watch this.

Quick warning, this review may contain major spoilers, so read at your own desecration.  
Little With Academia, has to be, by far, the best show Studio Trigger ever created.  It should be noted I’m not a big fan of Studio Trigger and by proxy Studio Gainax, only a handful of their shows peeking my interest, such as When Supernatural Battles Became Commonplace, Gurren Lagan, Panty & Stocking w/Garterbelt, and, to a much lesser extent, Neon Genesis Evangelion.  But Little Witch Academia impressed me on so many levels I don’t even know where to begin.  Think if Harry Potter was an anime…..andif all the main cast was female, not just one of them.  It stars Akko, an energetic middle school girl with aspirations of becoming a Witch.  When she enters Luna Nova, the magic school of the series, however, she finds it very difficult for several reasons; she’s a stubborn girl who doesn’t like to listen to others, almost everyone at the school hates her for most of the show and has no faith in her improving, and not to mention she really sucks at magic to the extent that she can’t even fly a broom, the reason of witch she isn’t aware of right away but is important to the plot.  The story is pretty by the numbers in terms of being a Harry Potter homage, there’s really very little originality here, but all the cliche’s it does use are executed so masterfully that you often forget that they even are cliche’s.  although it’s not flawless, it’s prob ably my favorite anime of 2017 at least, and an anime that everybody needs to watch, or at least try; this is especially true for Studio Trigger and Studio Gainax fans, but even if you aren’t, like me, it’s still worth a look.  


The best part of the show is the characters.  Every one of them are interesting, complex, and likable.  Even Diana and her two friends, Hannah and Barbara.  At first the three seemed like very typical, cruel, one-dimensional antagonists whose only purpose for existing was to torment Akko as she struggles.  While Hannah and Barbara don’t become incredibly complex, they do turn two-dimensional when Diana returns to her noble home and they show tremendous concern for her, even willingly chatting with Akko, informing her what’s going on, which they never would’ve done otherwise.  And then there’s Diana.  While it’s really easy to hate her during the first half of the s how, it’s when she returns home to deal with her family’s troubles that we learn more about her difficult lifestyle.  Akko assumes in her beginning that Diana was a prodigy of magic when she was young, but I truth she struggled just as much Akko.  It was even harder on Diana because of the pressures of living up to her noble lineage.  This naturally made her cold towards others, even after she obtained a mastery over magic.  She doesn’t hate Akko on the personal level, nor did she have any desire of being cruel and malicious to her, she just hated watching her goofing off and seemingly not taking her training seriously, unaware of the real reason she wasn’t able to use magic proficiently.  And she does eventually grow to think about Akko more positively eventually, the same as everyone else.  


I love each character in the main four.  Akko herself can be annoying at times, but she’s also likable and endearing.  She actually reminded me of Naruto in the early parts of that massive monster of a series; she’s a wild troublemaker, but not with malicious intentions, she just wanted to improve her craft, and more importantly to get others to notice her, by any means necessary, although she’s a lot less irritating than Naruto was back then.  Akko is just unbelievably endearing, almost everything she does either making me laugh, or at least smile, makes me tense, makes me cheer, especially later on in the show, or makes me emotional, and the conclusion of the show was very gratifying and made the journey Akko went through worthwhile.  Her friends, while not granted with as much development as her, are still fun in their own right.  There’s Lotte Yanson, a Finnish Witch whose typically quiet and reserved, but can be angry if she’s pushed too far, and Sucy Manbavaran, who also tends to be quiet, but has a rather dark sense of humor and loves to play tricks on Akko all in good fun.  The two aren’t very complex, but they are two-dimensional at least, and serve as great supports for Akko.  Due to beding stuck with her they often get lumped in with her misdeeds, especially if she’s late for something important, such as the Samhain Festival, but they end up growing a great bond with Akko that causes them to stick with her despite the criticism they get.  Their interactions was the most purely enjoyable part of watching this anime, it’s not often that I watch a show with friends so close that it makes me envy them, and this one accomplished that.  


There’s two more characters I want to discuss.  First, Ursula Callistis, aka Chariot du Nord, better known as Silver Chariot.  She was setup as Akko’s inspiration, a great Witch who put on a show for Akko and many others when Akko was just six years old, and it moved Akko so much that she wanted to become a Witch just like her.  Once she finally arrives at Luna Nova ten years later, however, Chariot has disappeared, and most people who know the name have nothing but negative things to say about her, which just baffles Akko.  Little Witch Academia had a huge risk of turning her into a Mary Sue, a perfect role model for Akko and everyone else around her.  Instead, she is just as flawed as every other major character.  For most of the show she was disguising herself as the teacher Ursula Calistis; the truth is only revealed to us when the show is almost done, all the while we get bits and pieces of foreshadowing to allude to this twist.  Chariot was very similar to Akko as a child; she had a huge passion for magic and wanted to make people happy, but she lacked the skill to achieve her dreams, causing many blunders.  She did, thankfully, overcome this, just like Akko, and became the Witch Silver Chariot that many young Witches revered.  Her biggest flaw actually turned out to be her kindness and desire to make people smile ;one day when performing, everyone’s expectations of her grew so great that she was crushed under the pressure to please them, shortly after abandoning the stage, taking on her identity as the teacher Ursula Calistis.  


The greatest twist involving her is that she was unknowingly the reason Akko was unable to use magic; when she stopped using her signature weapon, the Shiny Rod, magic power would be drained from her audiences whenever she put on a performance, which included Akko the day she saw one of those said performances.  The final character I wanna talk about is that of Croix Meridies, which is one of my only two major complaints about the show.  While she’s not a terrible character in general,s he did come off as a rather weak villain.  She’s interesting because, unlike the rest of the Witches in the show, she uses modern technology combined with magic, which is highly frowned upon by many Witches who value the old ways over the new ways.  She was old friends with chariot, who was pissed when she spirit inside the Arcturus Forest chose Chariot to wield the Shiny Rod instead of her.  Years later she came back to the school as a teacher, but her true intention was to awaken the Grand Triskellion, which was sealed inside of the Arcturus Forest, to bring a better, more peaceful future, loosing faith in the current generation of Witches being capable of that.  


Like I said, she’s not a terrible character, but for her story to work I feel it need a lot more buildup and back story.  I just felt like we got the bare bones of what was necessary to kind of understand who she is, but I felt it difficult to care about her personally, and I didn’t really understand her plans at all.  Not to mention, despite almost nuking the world, she was seemingly let off the hook at the end and allowed to leave Luna Nova again, which seemed ridiculous to me; I’m not saying the necessarily had to put her to death for what she did, but she would have still been punished in some way, but she wasn’t.  that didn’t come close to ruining the series for me, though, because all the other characters were so damn  great that having one sub-par character is pretty inconsequential.  I also found it disappointing that the whole “message” of the show happens to be “THE POWER OF LOVE AND FRIENDSHIP” which is so common in anime today, it just felt like a really stupid conclusion to an otherwise fantastic anime.  







The visuals are also incredible.  This anime has the best animation Studio Trigger has ever displayed; there isn’t as much moving as in Kill la Kill, but it makes up for it by having much more fluidity and less choppiness, which is what I care about more than actual movement.  Every single solitary cell in this show is breathtakingly beautiful, it’s an absolute joy to look at from start to finish.  The character designs are also nice, they have the anime style of large eyes, bright colors, and over exaggerated reactions, but still have a unique edge to them, too.  Overall, I loved this show, this is one of the most recent additions to my favorite anime of all time.  If Studio Trigger wanted to make a second season I would be all for it; hell, if they hosted another kickstarter to see if people wanted it, I would definitely support it, because it deserves more than just twenty five episodes than it got.  This is the first show I’ve seen from director Yoh Yoshinari, but I’ll definitely keep an eye out for him in the future.  





FINAL SCORE:  8/10

Magic should make people happy,and that was very apparent in Little Witch Academia..made by Studio Trigger..which give life and enjoyment to fans and peers alike with anime like Kill La Kill,A sensational and unique anime very much gave the same thrills we received in Little Witch Academia with eye-popping characters and unique art style with a mix of colourful and beautiful sceneries and relatable character traits and personality we felt during our lives.It's an anime that shows you a believing heart is truly magical.
Story (8.2)
The story starts off with a young girl wanting to be her favourite witch/idol which inspired her with her astonishing andfabulous magic tricks and eye-popping visuals that putting the hearts of many to believe in yourself.A good start and base for the Main Character but honestly quite bland I would say due to how much shows that use this story until it practically becomes's a standard for most anime.It also leaves the character to be anticipated much easily,in other words, predictable.Using the same 'don't give up and keep believing' term leaves the character to be less interesting and more generic.Overall, the story manages to counter this with some unexpected plot twist leaving the show back on for more surprises.


Art And Character Design (8.9)

So much effort has been put out for the beautiful background and character.Although...A portion from the anime community and critics,reviewers alike find the art style to be quite mediocre.

I however,find the art to be quite eye popping and the motions of these character movements,especially in key events blooms a much smooth and sometimes almost fluid-like movements.

I find that overall the art was quite satisfying and the character traits and traits blend really well with the art style that they compose in their show.So to say the art was mediocre, I personally disagree.Of course, there are some exceptions so few but clear for example over-use flashes and explosions heavily riddled with highlighted confusing bright colours alike but all of this cons have considered deteriorated due to how well the studio uses this to a method to show and moderate the character emotion and traits they believe and presents.


Verdict (Should You Watch?...Absolutely)

(9.1)

If you find yourself to have a fondness or even biased to inspirational anime alike that makes you want to chase your dream, then this anime is clearly for you.This anime teaches you that dream is possible if you work hard for it.'Simply dreaming won't make you grasp it, but work hard day after day, and you'll find it in your hand'. STAR ARC!!!

It's hard to talk about the Little Witch Academia series without talking about the original OVAs... but I'm going to try.
Little Witch Academia is an amazing creation -- not perfect, but impressive in almost every scale -- held back by a few glaring flaws.  I can recommend it pretty highly, but there are several caveats.
The story is probably the show's strongest suit... when it actually bothers to use it.  The series is paced very poorly, and I think I would regard it better overall if it had been a little tighter, or even if plot and character-building episodes had been better interwoven.Instead, we get a long, dragging first half that does build a lot of character but only introduces a few elements that are actually relevant for the story that the show ultimately tells.  The second half, on the other hand, is a whirlwind of character drama and events that does an amazing job of carrying the viewer on and, frankly, casts the weaknesses of the first half into sharp relief.


As far as the story itself, it's actually kind of unique.  At the risk of very minor spoilers, Little Witch Academia takes place in a universe where magic is becoming marginalized, even dying.  That in itself is fairly unique (at least for the "magical school" genre) and when Akko, our main character, is a young woman in love with magic, who sees beauty in it and wants others to do the same, it serves to make her struggle seem all the more relevant and human when it isn't exactly a foregone conclusion.


Speaking of characters, they're all very good.  There are at least nine or ten characters who get fairly full development over the running time of the show, and more who are in at least a couple episodes and you can regard, essentially, as 'people'.  The main adult characters (Professor Ursula and latecomer Professor Croix) are oddly the best studied and most well-rounded, which brings me to the flaw in the characters... Akko especially, and to a lesser extent her friends, can be hard to watch at times.  Akko's greatest trait, you see, is her zeal, which can get her into trouble as much as it gets her out of trouble, and that's fine, but it also gets her into quite a lot of awkward moments.  This isn't necessarily a bad decision, as it makes for a very distinct and flawed character, but it does lead to a few too many circumstances, especially in the first half, where I cringed at her behavior.  Similarly there were a few times where Sucy was just a little too mean-spirited for comfort and quite a lot before real character development kicked in where Diana's apparent perfection was really grating.  Ultimately, I found Diana to be the weakest character out of the expansive core cast; the episodes later on that covered her arc did a good job of explaining and humanizing her earlier appearances, but that doesn't exactly forgive the sour taste they left in my mouth.


As to the art and sound... they're good.  There's nothing truly jaw-dropping there; I watched in dub (a rarity for me) and the voice acting was very good, but that means I can't really speak to the original on that score.  The openings are both fairly fun even if they're not amazingly memorable, but the endings are forgettable, if pleasant.  The art design has a very good style that really does support showing off the magic and wonder of the world of Little Witch Academia, so in that way it's very good, even if there are times where the exaggerated expressions of characters go a little far from their main models.  That said, it doesn't really do anything that wows me.


So, that's the Little Witch Academia series on its own -- Highly recommended, but flawed.


Story - 9

Art - 9 

Sound - 8

Character - 9

Enjoyment - 8

Overall - 9


But let's say I did want to compare it to the OVAs.  How does it hold up?  Surprisingly, as someone who really liked the OVAs, I think the series might ever be better.  For all its faults, like the pacing, or Diana's earlier character, there's something that's beautiful, even magical, about the world as it exists fully realized in the show as opposed to the more thinly sketched universe of the OVAs.  Especially compared to the first OVA, with its monster-filled dungeon under the school, the Luna Nova and world around it we see in the show has better internal consistency without loosing too much of the sense of wonder that made the original so great.  Magical Parade is a closer comparison, as it introduced a lot of elements that were repeated in the show, but even then Magical Parade can't and doesn't go into the same careful depth that the show does.  So while they are different, and I can totally understand being of the opposite opinion, I think the series is actually my favorite version.

I greatly enjoyed this anime from start to finish! I had watched the movie when it first was released and I am so glad they continued with an anime later on. The art is beautiful, the animation is nice and smooth, and the characters are adorable and relatable. The story is not too bad either! I actually quite enjoyed the story and found it inspiring. Many of us have someone we look up to, someone we idolize. This anime really showed how you can be your own person, and how you do not have to completely be like the person you idolize to be great.I believe young adults will really like this anime if not for the life lesson. \n

Amazing? ABSOLUTELY YES!! I was so hyped for this series when I first saw the short films. I personally love the fantasy and magic genre, and I'm so glad this series turned out to be amazing, since a part of me was prepared for this to be a failure. I would love to give this a 10/10, but one thing has prevented me from doing so. Seeing the first 10 or so episodes, I was instantly hooked on this series. The anime made a turn from the fantasy school comedy genre to a more serious sci-fi adventure halfway through. Don't get me wrong, I lovedthe entire series, but I feel like that change of storytelling came too suddenly, which is why I can't consider this a true 10/10. But oh man! The ending was also just beautiful in every way possible, almost perfect in my opinion. What can I say? I love Atsuko's character. Is she cringy? Yes... Does she have any shame at all? Probably not... But nonetheless, her character was so lovable all the way through, even if she's a bit annoying at times lol. The soundtrack of this entire show really shows the ideal fantasy track. The tracks are epic when need be, and also incredibly radiant. And of course, you can't forget the "a believing heart is our magic" line. Call me childish if you want, but I love lines like those! And you can't ignore the stunning animation done by Trigger studios, who has done many visually stunning works in the past such as Kill la Kill and Kiznaiver. So should you watch it? Yes! If you've read this entire post and you're still not impressed, please still give it a watch anyways!

This a great anime to enjoy with friends or any family member, it got that disney like of show combine with the Harry Potter series. But at the same time creates something unique with the characters and the story. 
On to the negative of this show, the story it was good but no that excel of other past show from Trigger and the OVA where better overall because of the length. This show it is better in a movie format than series and it tells because some episodes feel like they where trying to stretch the story. I know this will not the same buti wish the ending was bit more flashy like Kill la Kill or Space Patrol Luluco.


The positive, the art was out the charts with a lot of animation and with beautiful colors scenes. The main characters are really lovable and they it develop much more then OVA. The opening and ending song are great the get you hype to watch the episodes and relaxing when you end one.


Overall for me this is a cult hit anime than in time will gain it popularity, but i hope the make it into a movie series than a tv show.

I tried. I really tried my hardest to go into this anime to watch it critically, and not get so sucked in to the world and the characters. I find that when I do this, my emotions get wrapped up in the lives of the characters, and I begin to fall in love with them in an instant.
For awhile, this worked. 
"Little Witch Academia" follows Atsuko Kagari, or Aukko for short, a bubbly young witch who hopes to become like her idol Shiny Chariot at Luna Nova Academy. Over the course of 25 episodes, you see the ins and outs of Aukko's time at LunaNova and how she truly grow progress despite how much she has going up against her. You also see the lives and trails other characters face around Aukko, and how they all grow to become better people.


I started this anime with the mindset that it couldn't suck me in. The first episode, I was a bit annoyed with a few things but found it to be charming, the second episode was really good but I still didn't think much of it, and by episode six I was so invested in the show I couldn't stop thinking about where the rest of the series would go with it's premise. I watched the entire show in under a week, and I really wish I had taken my time with it. I honestly miss the show, and all of the characters that played a role in it.


 Also, this story is so visually interesting. The world of Luna Nova, the town the characters occasionally run through, it is all so pretty. Aukko has some of the best animation on her though, with all of her often absurd and hilarious reactions. The backgrounds are so lovely, I can't give enough praise to just how much I love the art design of this show. 


Now, for the characters...I will mostly talk about the ones that really stuck out to me, in order to keep this short. I did really enjoy all the other characters, though.


Aukko is an amazing lead character; built on a burning desire to live her dream, a very stubborn attitude, and she can often be incredibly childish...I couldn't help but cheer her on. Does Aukko always make the best decisions? No, but that is what makes her character interesting. I want to see Aukko succeed because she is repeatedly beat down through out the series. Often labeled as someone of not much worth to Luna Nova, Aukko's ambitious nature keeps her moving past a lot of the often cruelty of the other witches. I really like that.


Sucy towards the beginning of this anime was honestly what frustrated me the most; I found her to be annoying, rude, and really mean-spirited. Luckily, she does grow to like Aukko a lot towards the end of the series, and you can see that really shine in the lest few episodes. While I didn't consistently enjoy Sucy, I did think she could be quite funny at points. I just feel a lot of her more humorous points were often overshadowed by this really mean nature. 


Andrew is terrible, I really don't mind saying that. While I grew to appreciate him towards the end of the series, he felt like such a flawless, generic love interest that it did make me roll my eyes when he was onscreen. I didn't really buy his and Aukko's relationship, either. Honestly, I found Frank and Lotte's relationship to be much more cute than Andrew and Aukko's, but that is just my opinion. 


Diana Cavendish is the best character of the entire series, hands down. Diana, towards the first half o the series, seems more like the typical school bully at times, but as the series progresses you see she isn't really out to be mean to anyone in particular. Diana is just bored of the magic she has grown to know, and shoves so many of her emotions downward that it has left her rather cold. Aukko has what Diana needs, a passion for magic, and Diana has what Aukko needs, maturity and training. I love the relationship that forms between these two characters. It is something really astounding, and I loved to watch Diana slowly grow to respect Aukko's place at Luna Nova more and more. I love Diana, and I could sing praise for her constantly.


On that note, I loved Little Witch Academia. Did I have a bit of problem with a few of the characters? Yes, but that wasn't an ongoing problem, and it fizzed out by the end of the series. Little Witch may be sappy and corny to some, with it's talk of dreams and believing in yourself, but it does it in such a heartwarming and sweet way that I recommend this anime to anyone and everyone who hasn't seen it. This isn't just your typical "magical girl" or "witch" anime, the show is lined with turns, and incredible world building and character development. 


Give it a try, I guarantee you won't be disappointed.


"Believe in yourself, and in your heart!"

Can somebody who hasn’t seen the OVAs formulate a valuable review about Little Witch Academia? Well, I’ll take it one step further, I haven’t even seen Harry Potter! Ha!
Story:
We follow the (mis)adventures of a hyperactive girl named Akko as she tries to become a formidable witch like her big idol Shiny Chariot. That’s easier said than done, as Akko is really bad at magic, and I mean BAD. The general buildup of the 25 episodes is not that different from what Kill La Kill did. At first, we get a lot of mundane, slice of lifey episodes and the plot merely being mentioned, but notfocused on. Around halfway through it starts taking over and the lightheartedness gets less (though it never completely vanishes). I like this kind of slow increase of seriousness, because I like to enjoy both, the relaxed and the tense sides of the work’s world. For some, this change may not be what they wish for, I however enjoyed it. The story itself is not too extraordinary, it’s the classic quest to achieve a goal, not unlike what many shounen series look like. I can’t say that this anime is void of plot holes, but due to other outstanding factors, it never feels important whether everything is perfectly coherent or not, something Trigger seems to have mastered. Long story short, the plot is nothing special, but executed well.

7/10


Art:

If you know the Trigger style, you know exactly what to expect. Though I have to say, while their other shows were using many over-realistic or hard-edged shots when going into the extreme, Little Witch Academia remains relatively calm and smooth in general. The producers said they wanted to make a family-friendly show and this also shows in the artwork. Of course this also means tons of bright colors, to a point where the anime gets a bit of a cartoony feel. The Western influence is highly visible in Little Witch Academia. As with KonoSuba, I dig this hybrid style and for a show like this, it feels very right. The special effects are spread throughout the series in moderation, but nonetheless look very beautiful. Prime examples are episodes 6 and the final one. Bonus points for the Merrie Melodies/Silly Symphonies/Fleischer style clips from episode 8.

10/10


Sound:

Megumi Han does a fantastic job as Akko. Her voice emits all the fun the character is made of, but she also works in more serious moments. All other main characters have fitting voices for their personalities, especially Sucy, who sounds like a wicked witch out of a kid’s nightmare (isn’t that a perfect description for her?). On a personal note, I always chuckle a little when I hear “Naruto” in a serious role. The opening and ending songs were all solid, the second opening is quite catchy and slowly starting to grow on me. This show also uses background music very efficiently. I mentioned before, that I get the feeling that orchestral soundtracks are used more often in recent anime and I think that is a wonderful development. Provided of course that this statement is true and not my weird subjective impression due to the anime I choose to watch. The Little Witch Academia soundtrack is similar to what you may hear in a movie, which may or may not be another nod to the West. Anyway, I think it fits very well and gives emotional scenes more impact.

9/10


Characters:

This is one of the strongest parts of Little Witch Academia. There are so many fun characters for everybody’s liking that I fail to see how anybody could not at least find one suiting their tastes. Akko is very similar to a shounen protagonist in many ways, but she is such an upbeat, positive girl, that I can’t bring myself to dislike her, even though I’m not a fan of those archetypes. If you don’t like Akko, then how about Diana? At first it seems she is going to be the bitch rival, but she happens to be a very honest and humble person, who just happens to take things more seriously than Akko. We also have lots of fun side characters, like the complete maniac Sucy, the adorable sweetheart Lotte, the tomboyish Amanda, the grumpy genius Constanze and many more. Even characters like Hanna and Barbara, who are complete jerks, are likeable by being just too goofy to take seriously. In total, all characters were either well written or fun side characters. If I have to criticize something, it’s the fact that Andrew had little involvement in the overall plot. I just wish he would have done something important along the way. As it is, his scenes are really pointless, as he is also too serious to be fun on his own. Just give him an unrequited crush on somebody or whatever. Another, though very minor, problem of such a colorful cast is that you can hardly flesh them out much. As I said, they are fun, but I want to know more about them too.

9/10


Enjoyment:

I have drawn some parallels to Kill La Kill and that for a simple reason. Not (only) because they are both Trigger shows, but because they work in the same manner. They are what I think I called “brainless fun” in my KLK review, but that isn’t a very endearing term. What I mean by that is that anime don’t need to be deep or have constant gags to be entertaining, it also works to have a coherent story to tell and do so in a way that just screams “fun”. I repeat that word over and over, but that’s because that is the one big message I get from Little Witch Academia. I am positive that most of you will have a good time watching this show, I sure as hell did.

10/10


Overall:

9.0/10

***This is a spoiler free review***
When I first saw the original OVA episode of Little Witch Academia I almost had my fundamental understanding of the video medium turned upside down. How did Studio Trigger cram such a satisfying story into 40 minutes? How did they make it not seem like a rushed mess? 
I wanted to see more of this work and while the second OVA helped with this, it felt lacking. Now however we have a full double cour tv series that features the same lovable cast with interesting magical adventures. 
Plot: 7/10
Sort of a mixed bag here. The first season was almost entirelya sectioned off bit of short stories (like the first and second OVA). While key events in certain episodes show character development, there really is no overarching plot development. The first season is very much a sort of slice-of-life show with the magical elements. The second season however kicks it into full gear with a plot that stays relevant throughout the remainder of the series. These episodes in the second season are in my opinion where the show really shines. There are some awesome moments in the first season but for the most part since there is no sort of plot progression I view them less satisfying compared to the second season.


Art/Animation: 9/10


Very, very good in my opinion. They were able to keep the visual style (art) intact from the OVAs which was a crucial thing to accomplish. The characters look great and in Trigger style the clothing looks amazing. Trigger always seems to nail a sort of modern yet world fitting fashion sense. In Kiznaiver I feel like they hit new strides in how good and fitting fashion can fit into an anime. 


The animation quality was in my opinion also great. Yes this is a tv series so the amount of expressive animation is limited due to budgeting and time constraints but I feel like Trigger did a great job picking and choosing where to shine. The action shots look pretty amazing and even the more low key shots stand out due to...the Trigger style. 


Sound: 10/10


Simply perfect. The OST fits in so well with the magical setting of LWA. People say the series is just Harry Potter but with magic girls; they wouldn't be wrong but it is because of the music that it feels this way. I don't know exactly wait entails a magic feeling audio queue but LWA has it, everywhere. The voice actors are simply amazing. They bring out their characters perfectly. The on-screen animations help too but it's the VA's ability to really express their characters. 


Characters: 9.5/10
