I feel like the character development in the show did wonders for the universe of LWA. There were so many questions left unanswered/up in the air after the OVAs. The tv series really expanded on the main characters while adding a few awesome new ones. The character interactions are the main stars here. Every since one of them feel full of emotion, excitement, and in some cases sorrow. Just everything about the characters is spot on. I just wish it carried through all the episodes instead of in certain early ones and all of the second half. 


Overall: 8.9/10


This was absolutely an amazing ride. The show had exactly what I wanted; more magical school adventures with the main cast that I fell in love with in the OVAs. The tv series took a little while to get fully started but once it did, I was falling in love with the world all over again. If you want magic school Harry Potter but in high school girl form, watch this tv series after watching at least the first LWA OVA episode. You will not regret it. 


Enjoyment: 9/10


Thanks for reading my review! If you liked my writing style, would like to see some other reviews, or just want to talk, please stop by my page!


Sincerely,

Awesome Drummer

Growing up as a kid, I still fondly remember the times of watching old-school animated Disney movies. You know, the kinds of movies that featured a magical world that just drew you into the depths of it's fantastical story and by the end, left you with a feeling of utter amazement and confidence. For me, Little Witch Academia (LWA) brings back many of those youthful feelings of nostalgia. 
-Overview:
The story starts out with a young witch, Atsuko Kagari (Akko), who has a dream of becoming a great witch just like her idol, Shiny Chariot (a magical performer), whose performance inspired her to take up witchcraft.To pursue this goal, she enrolls into Luna Nova Academy, an ancient school that is renowned for training competent and amazing witches. Along the way, she meets many friends, rivals, and people who she looks to for guidance. However, her path towards becoming a great witch isn't one without hardships and adversity.


-Story:


The story of LWA primarily revolves around Akko who, despite having zero talent for magic, strives to become a great witch just like her idol, Shiny Chariot. Due to her lack of magical talent and impulsiveness, she's often the laughing stock of her classmates, and experiences failures on a daily basis. However, despite that, she still tackles each obstacle head-on and never gives up on her dream. The old adage of "hard work pays off", is definitely a central theme in this anime. Of course, no man (or witch) is an island. In Akko's case, that's where her friends and mentor come in, to provide support, encourage, and inspire her in times when she's at her lowest. Throughout the story, Akko learns not only to believe in herself (but to believe in the Kamina tha- Sorry), but to also believe and put faith in those around her. After all, the prominent quote in this anime is "A believing heart is your magic".


As a side-note: The first half of the story is pretty much episodic in nature. It's essentially a slice of life series revolving around witches in a magic academy. It's really not until a little over half-way through that the plot really starts to take hold. While I personally enjoyed the early episodes, I've heard of a few who haven't, so I thought I'd mention it to any would-be readers. Although, I'd strongly suggest watching through the first half, since the story only gets better with time. 


-Characters:


Pretty much all of the main characters in this anime are very well done. Akko is your classic happy go lucky dunce of a girl who you can't help but love, Lotte is your shy and reserved bookworm who cares deeply for her friends, and Sucy who is a mischievous, slightly sadistic,  and smug girl who has an unnatural fondness for mushrooms and deadly poisons. Diana is Akko's rival and polar opposite. She comes from a distinguished family of witches and values tradition and elegance above all else. It's because of this that the two often get into confrontations with one another because of their opposing worldviews and personalities. However, despite being stern, Diana is actually a very compassionate and caring person that shares more in common with Akko than she lets on. Akko's primary mentor and guidance councilor comes in the form of Ursula, who's a teacher at Luna nova. She's a caring and thoughtful woman who tries to guide Akko down the right path and gives her much advice along the way. I think what I enjoyed most about the characters is the synergy that they shared with one another, specifically among Akko, Sucy, Lotte, and Diana. They don't just automatically becomes friends with each other as if it was preordained. It's not even to say that they're alike in any way, but after spending time together, they learn more about each other and come to a mutual understanding which makes their friendship actually seem significant. Also, while the characters may not be the most complex out there, but they each have enough depth to them which makes their characters interesting and unique. 


As for the antagonist of the story, they're not your typical villain. Especially, once you know their motivations and goals, they're actually pretty understandable, which is something that I can appreciate. 


-Animation and Music:


The animation is done by studio Trigger, who is widely known for their signature style of animation. Sometimes the animation is completely goofy and cartoonish, while other times it's serious and incredibly detailed and vibrant. It's good when it needs to be good (emotional moments, fight scenes, etc), and OK in less significant scenes. There's a few off models that I noticed here and there, but I can't really fault them for that (in fact, some are quite hilarious).


The music is frankly fantastic. Bright orchestral scores with violins, catchy and beautiful openings, nothing is necessarily overdone or overpowering, but fits in perfectly with the theme and tone of the series. 


-Overall:


I honestly enjoyed every second of watching Little Witch Academia. Unlike many anime, it's an honest series that stays true to it's vision and never compromises it's integrity. It's a wholesome and fun show that you can watch with family, friends, and, well....just about anybody.

Animated by the legendary anime studio TRIGGER, Little Witch Academia tells the story of Atsuko "Akko" Kagari, an aspiring young witch who enrolls at the Luna Nova Academy.   While initially reminiscent of Harry Potter, the series quickly captures the viewers heart as a tale of it's own.  Akko friends include the laughably sadistic, mushroom-crazed, Sucy and timid, kind-hearted, Lotte. 
     Although a Japanese title, Little Witch Academia makes several references aimed at Western culture throughout the series.  The writers are also talented at unfolding what seems like an initially simple castof characters into a group of individuals which are more complex than their initial appearance. The series truly blossoms into something memorable.


      The Little Witch Academia Television series will make you laugh, cheer, and cry.  It's not to say the series isn't without flaws, only that the few rushed moments and animated oddities sprinkled here and there are entirely forgivable.  


The series really is incredible. Watch it, and remember:


"A believing heart is your magic!"

Little Witch Academia review
With a new and captivating concept , with stunning visuals and vivid characters LWA is one of those shows that leave a good impression for its audience after watching it.
When we were kids we all have something we wanted to do when we grow up, we all had  dreams and  the determination to work hard for our dreams. 
Well this is how our story in LWA starts with our main heroine Akko  who views  a magic show , captivated by it she falls in love with the magic and the one who performs it  Chariot. She thendecides to follow in her footsteps and go to  LWA to achieve her dream . 


In a total new world and full of mysteries and magic Akko  experiences new emotions that she never felt ,meets new people and makes friends and rivals and under the guide of her mentor Ursula she learns more about magic . This experience helps her  to discover more about her own identity and what struggles she must overcome to achieve her dream.


The most impressive thing that this anime left are the characters raw  emotions  especially from our heroine Akko.  During her  journey to find the seven lost words from her magical staff Chariot , she learns the meaning behind those words experiencing different emotional states. With the help of the beautiful visuals those raw emotions  are well exposed to its audience captivating and creating an emotional atmosphere. 


The thematic exploration is very rich for its audience in LWA , themes as dreams, determination, hardworking, emotions, traditionalism vs modern times are questioned and executed with the help of our characters. Having a different range of themes is always good but what matters is how they are explored and brought forward to it’s audience.


The characters in LWA are  really  what makes this show worth watching. Akko the clumsy and straightfoward idiot who never gives up after she fails having a dream that keeps her going on.  She represents the hardworking type who has to start from zero with no talent at all which we all can relate from our real life. Diana who everyone from LWA depends on her knowledge in magic and asks her to solve different problems involving the academy. At first she is mistaken as an elite with a snob attitude but as we get to know more about her circumstances and story we all appreciate her sacrifices and responsibilities she faced since young age. 


Lotte and Sucy despite their lack of characterization explored , from their interactions with Akko and other members from Lwa we get to know more about them. We find out about Sucy who is mad scientist who likes to experiment different poisons and mushrooms  , Lotte who is a book worm and has the ability to speak with fairies since young age.  A flaw for this anime is the lack of characterization for the minor characters who later will influence the plot and story and Akko’s development.


What I liked in this anime was the fact that they put in debate the theme about traditionalism vs modern times. It was done with the help of a new character introduced Croix who changes the whole believes and appearance in LWA with her new magic  development.  The anime critique the modern society who is too depended on the technology and presented the consequences without it ,  and presented a contrast between magic and science who can coexist together.


The visuals play an important role for the main plot and story in LWA. With the help of them  the emotional state of characters and experiences are conveyed to its audience. “Emotions are magic” probably one of my favorites metaphors from LWA , were the visuals help and portray how the human emotions are conveyed into magic energy .


Little Witch Academia is an anime that motivates and persuades its audience to follow his dreams , advises them to not choose the easy path and run away from struggles  but overcome them, to strive for a place , to open your heart and rely on your friends or dear persons in hardships times  and finally to follow your raw emotions and believe in your own strength.

I just finished watching the final episode and oh my goodness, what a beautiful, amazing journey it was, I am overwhelmed by so many different emotions and I feel like I am about to tear up. I still can't believe this anime is over as it seems like only yesterday the first episode came out and I couldn't wait for more of Akko's adventures and shenanigans. But it's over, and maybe we will get to see our little witches again. At least I hope so.
Story: 10/10.
When I was little, I was obsessed with a show called The Worst Witch (now I know it's based offa series of books, but back then the TV show was the only thing I knew of), and Little Witch Academia reminds me of said show as Akko, let's admit it, is the worst witch of the 21st century. Inspired by Shiny Chariot and her magical shows, Atsuko Kagari, also known as Akko for short, came to Luna Nova in hopes of becoming the greatest witch this world has ever seen. But it turns out that the magical society has never approved of Chariot and her stage performances, so our naive protagonist ends up facing several hardships, be it boring classes and her inability to cast even simple spells or the witches' opinion on Shiny Chariot and their disapproval.

While the idea is pretty simple (and the idea of schools of witchcraft and wizardry is not new, remember Harry Potter and The Worst Witch, for example), there is a certain charm in this story as it is truly magical and inspiring. Eventually, all details begin to make more and more sense, falling into their places for us to see the whole picture. Little Witch Academia is epic, beautiful and charming in a way that makes you feel like a kid again. Remember those times when you believed in magic and miracles or liked to pretend they existed? That's the kind of show that brings all these warm memories back and I thank it for that.


Art: 9/10.

I love TRIGGER's art style and animation. After seeing Kill la Kill, I kind of expected this show to be epic in terms of angles, action and motion and I was right. I noticed (and maybe I am just imagining things) that in the last episode the art style and the quality of animation became a bit more sloppy, which is why I cannot give the art 10 out of 10, but let's give this show some credit for beautiful character designs, visual effects, scenery and animation, alright?


Sound: 10/10.

Little Witch Academia has a great soundtrack. At times it's epic (just remember its main theme that is associated with Shiny Chariot and great adventures), at times it's beautiful (I still can't get over Professor Woodward's first appearance in the show). The voice actors did a great job as all voices fit characters perfectly. That's the reason why my rating for this aspect is 10 out of 10, the sound in this anime definitely deserves it.


Character: 10/10.

Let's start with Akko, as she is the protagonist and one of the most interesting characters in this show. She is the worst witch of Little Witch Academia as she can hardly cast spells and, even when they do work, the result is far from what she or her teachers expect. She is naive, loud and noisy, as well as very stubborn. I did not always approve of her actions as sometimes they lacked common sense or any sort of wisdom. She acts first and then thinks about the consequences. But she never gives up. If she fails, she tries again and again and she is willing to learn because admitting defeat halfway through means giving up on her dream. Can't afford that. Which is why I like Akko. I like her because she is imperfect but, instead, our little witch is realistic. She makes mistakes yet she refuses to stop and that, ladies and gentlemen, is a very valuable lesson to learn, don't you think?

Her friends, Lotte and Sucy, sometimes act as the voice of reason because Akko doesn't have any real knowledge of how the magical world and society work, driven mostly by her dream and Shiny Chariot's show. Even though they do not get as much attention as I believe they should have, they are very charismatic and adorable in their own ways. And you know why? Because they have solid and well-established personalities. Lotte is a quiet, somewhat shy and kind-hearted girl and, in comparison to her sassy friend Sucy, she is more soft-spoken (can you believe that her seiyuu also voiced Rukia? now that's what I call talent). In the meantime, Sucy is cunning, sarcastic and even somewhat sadistic at times. All three girls are different yet their friendship grows stronger with each episode as the show goes on. And by the end of this show, you can't help but feel like you've known them for years, thinking of them as your friends.

Another witch the show is focused on is Diana Cavendish, a talented and bright student, everyone loves her and thus, you might get the impression that she is a Mary Sue. She's not, though. She is a serious, calm and collected person who takes her responsibilities seriously. It is hard to talk about this character without spoiling the plot to people who are just planning to watch this anime, but, if you ask me, I've always believed that there was so much more to her. Needless to say, I wasn't mistaken. Akko sees her as a rival and at the beginning Diana is portrayed in a somewhat negative light, but you can't help but notice that you can't hate her. Furthermore, sometimes you cannot agree with Akko.

On the other hand, Diana's teammates are less pleasant individuals and they can be pretty annoying at the beginning. But oh boy, I would like to thank the creators for taking time to develop these minor characters as well, that was truly amazing.

Now, let's talk about Shiny Chariot, currently known as Professor Ursula (it is not a spoiler as it's been confirmed in the original OVA), is one of the key figures of this story. A mysterious witch Akko admires while the rest of the magical society has little to no respect for her, believing that her magical shows were giving people the wrong idea of magic and witches. As Professor Ursula, she guides Akko like an older sister. She plays a very important role in Akko's life and all I can say without revealing too many details is, it's not just about her being a role model Akko wants to be like. Ursula a.k.a. Chariot has been one of my favorite characters ever since I saw the OVA and I was so happy to get to know her and her backstory better.

No, I am not done yet. Not until I give some credit to Amanda O'Neil, her team, Andrew Hanbridge and his friend Frank. While they are just minor characters, TRIGGER bothered giving them all a chance to grow and contribute to the plot. Sometimes it is hard to say anything about minor characters, they exist, they may be okay, they may be annoying, but in this case, they are all likable and sometimes it's almost impossible not to think of them as the members of the main cast.

Overall, this show has plenty of interesting and likable characters that grow and develop as the story goes on. A cast I have zero complaints about is a rarity and I have to tell you, guys, I already miss these characters, even though the show just ended. It reminds me of how I refused to say good bye to Kill la Kill. Thank you, TRIGGER, once again.


Enjoyment: 10/10.

Little Witch Academia is beautiful. It was funny, it could be sad and it was, without a doubt, epic. 25 episodes were not even remotely enough and I am hoping for a new season (I've heard on the grapevine that the creators want to make a show that'll be focused on Chariot, but rumors are just rumors and that remains to be seen).


I am going to miss Little Witch Academia. After seeing the OVA, I wanted it to get a show of its own. And now this show is over. It was a great adventure. Good bye, little witches, let's meet again someday, I will be waiting.

Little Witch Academia was an amazing intersection between magic and anime. I almost never write reviews, but this certainly warranted one. This reminded me of the reason that I love Harry Potter so much: through the characters and the world that is created it has the power to capture the imagination in a pretty surreal way. The characters were really well-developed, the music is great (especially OP2 - MIND CONDUCTOR by YURiKA) and the story itself was always funny and suspenseful. The art itself might seem a bit childish at first but trust me its perfect for what it is trying to convey. There aremultiple characters in this anime that grow up and realize how naive they were which hits home with me and many others.\n\n
I can't remember the last time I was grinning while watching an entire anime. It just has the ability to make you feel all nice and fuzzy inside. If you like magic this is a no brainier. If this is your first anime I think it is a great representation of what anime should be: heartfelt art. Highly recommended!!!

Little Witch Academy came up with an interesting premise - though not a new one - for a new Trigger series. Yoshinari as director is showing his maturation. Although the first episodes passed the impression of an experimentation, from the middle of the first cour of the series we could see sketches of serious development, small changes of tone that would make you see the characters and the story not as something episodic, as sometimes Gave the impression. The development of the main character, Akko was somewhat inaccurate, but managed to consolidate throughout the series. My only complaint with the director would be the beginning,which, as I said, passed the impression of experimentation, and also with the fact that there was no further development of the other characters; Something that the direction was due. Still the plot and the plot gave a good taste to this deficiency of the direction of the series, and knew to work with her.

"It gets better as it goes in" is definitely something someone should go into this when starting for the first time.
The first 12-13 episodes aren't the best, nothing really goes anywhere, I can describe those episodes as maybe more alike Lupin III. So if you don't have a problem with that sort of format, you'll be fine, if not, stick with it, once you get past the roadblock, it makes for some really entertaining watching.
You don't really need to have seen the OVA and movie to really understand what's going on. The show starts at Akko's induction into Luna Nova and takes off from there.However, I would recommend checking them out at least, if you can, as they're also some really good watching.\n\n
The world, the characters, the whole feel of the show clicked with me instantly. Each characters are varied, the clash between old magic and new modern traditions makes for some interesting scenarios that take place in the show.\n\n
All in all, is this worth a watch? Of course. If you enjoyed Trigger's previous works, you'll most likely enjoy this. If you're like me and didn't like Kill La Kill (the only trigger series i'd heard of before starting this), it'll probably take some time before you get into it. I'd recommend the OVA and/or movie so you can get an idea about what the show is about and whether or not it is for you.

This is in many parts very different from the original anime pilots that this came from. But this fitted for this 25 parter perfectly. The story came full circle and was crowned with perfect ending. 
      As Akko the protagonist may seem at first a bit annoying and some episodes mainly on first half for those who are not that fond of slice to life animes. The first episodes really feel like everyday occurrences in a witch academy and the pacing is a bit slow and things may get a bit repetitive. When episodes go by you realize that theydeveloped characters and relationships through that time and fro the half wayish point "the plot" can really kick start. \n
       There really was reason for all of things we saw and experienced and the ending is the final piece that binds everything neatly together. With Trigger-studios amazing art, especially on action scenes, the anime feels like it is pulling you in. This is a great anime as an entirety and would be a great marathon anime. This gets 9.1/10 and rounded to 9/10. It was really a delight to see the story come together at the end.

“Believing heart is everyone’s magic”
The main message of this show is really simple - believing can get you everywhere. If you think “hey, that’s so childish and naive” than, yes, you’re right, it is. Even if unrealistic, it’s still beautiful and somewhat motivating. This show doesn’t try to be believable or even “make sense” all of the time, and it isn’t about that. It’s about that indomitable positivity of the young heart, the one that most of us forgot about, but still have deep within. I definitely felt like a little kid when watching this series, I cherished my favorite characters, kept my fingers crossedwhen they were put to the test and felt down when they experienced hardships. But, one emotion was more significant than others - pure and uncontrollable happiness. I literally jumped on my chair when I watched final battle and couldn’t stop myself from smiling in both agitation and satisfaction. Although emotionally the show had mainly positive impact on me, I can’t say it was perfect or even near it….


Story:

The story goes around Akko, our main character - a witch as hopeless in magic as good in staying positive despite it. Her actions are usually reckless and because of that she constantly gets into trouble. She may seem quite selfish and ego-centered at first, but as show goes we see through that first impression and are able to see that most of her “mistakes” are caused by her cute and harmless stupidity, not by egoism. 

Main plot line is about collecting the “Words”, 7 spells which when collected have a power to break the seal of Grand Triskellion. Every word has its own meaning and represents not only plot progress, but also Akko’s development as a character. The message of each word is quite simple. They are casual teachings, like “be yourself” or “friendship is… nice” which can be found in most tales like this.

When we don’t see much innovations in that matter, execution of it is pretty nice. We really feel that acquiring and fully understanding them is associated with hardships and can only be achieved by oneself. 


Story had some plot problems. I know it is mostly directed to children, but even though, some things made absolutely 0 sens, like:

- Croix receiving none punishment after what she did

- Noone realizing that Croix is responsible for all this, when her robots fly in front of everyone's eyes all the time

-Ursula Sensei not telling anyone about Croix’s laboratory, or even none teachers visiting it

-Characters completely changing personalities after one event (Croix, Daryl, etc.) 

-and probably much more…


I think the last arc is the weakest one in the mean of plot tightness, which weakens the most emotional moments that take place in it. Overall, it is 

a entertaining story meant to make you more feel than think.


Characters:

The main cast is well written, their development looks believable and their characters are interesting. We have a wide range of personalities, from Akko - imaginative and extroverted type to Lotte - soft and introverted. I think I can say, that everyone can “pick” something for themselves, no matter if you prefer more spontaneous and adventurous character, or the reserved and hard-working. 

Characters are able to surprise, even when they are present from the very beginning, we still can anticipate some major changes or at least explanations for their behaviour.

When front line characters are well developed and interesting, the further plan ones are… well made too. Really, they personalities aren’t as complex, they can even be as flat as “the one who eats all the time”, but they still serve a purpose in the story and aren’t there just to fill the void. When you don’t like every one of them, you can at least understand their actions.


Art:

The art is very bright and colorful, like, Really colorful. The lines are strong, but animation can get way out-shape, which results in goofy, lighthearted experience. I particularly liked the face expressions of Akko, which were able to go grotesque in a second and return to normal right away. Hair movement was pretty too, many girl had different hairstyles, so watching them fly all around when they were riding brooms was really satisfying. As to magic… I wasn’t that impressed, most spells contained some green floating balls, and caused its effects in a poof of smoke...

The best moment of animation and fight choreography was in the final battle against the missle. The way that Akko uses her shape-changing abilities to dodge all the attacks and counters them... It was awesome!


Music:

It was great. It was mainly orchestra produced, so we are able to hear a lot of instruments. The similar motives are present throughout all the series, but many rearrangements made them sound fresh and entertaining. I said that motives repeat, but that doesn’t mean, that there are a few of them, the opposite is true. I never experienced a feeling, that music repeats itself, not when it wasn’t intended. When it was, like when Akko and Diana were fighting and people were cheering them it felt amazing and unique. Openings and endings were really nice, they had that light-hearted vibe and were good expositions of what we can see in the actual show.


Overall I consider this show a good entertainer. It won’t force us to deep reflections or to ask ourselves philosophical questions. Even though, it isn’t mindless, and shouldn’t be considered as such. The message it’s trying to deliver is childish and simple, yes, I agree, but that doesn’t debunk it’s validity. The real world isn’t a place as simple and idealistic as the one portrayed in the anime, but that doesn’t mean the believing heart can’t spark some magic in it...

Okay, I watched this on Netflix and part of it with my mom who does not usually watch anime because it’s not really her thing, we enjoyed this series fine enough, but until the plot actually happens it’s pretty filled with…filler. But hey, pretty to look at!
STORY:
6/10
When it actually happens, pretty good and interesting. I liked the world setting and the magic system was cool to learn about. The amount of filer in the middle however, grew pretty old for me pretty quick. And also the same story elements being dragged on for literal episodes (WhO iS cHaRiOt GeE wHiZ iDk Is ShE sTiLl AlIvE?!?!?!!).
ART:
9/10
Reallypretty, fit the story well and was fun to watch! Nothing like…that hasn’t been done before that blew my mind but a very pretty show!


SOUND:

7/10

The openings and ending were good, I wasn’t a huge fan of it/paid a lot of attention to it, I liked the visuals of them more then the actual sounds LOL


CHARACTER:

3/10

Gimmicks. SO MANY GIMMICK CHARACTERS. There were a few with potential that I expected to learn more about like, say, Suizie and Dottie who we meet in the first episode. We get a couple episodes with them mostly featured but then that’s pretty well it…like I think there’s just a huge portion of the show where they literally just get…forgotten about LOL.

I like Diana and what we got to see and learn about her, she was probably one of (if not the?) best developed character, I remember the most about her.

Akko is a screaming girl with a dream to be the best witch and gets through life with sheer volume and plot devices, she’s a fine typical MC and at least she wasn’t OP like plenty of boring main characters but her trait of being “really bad at magic” was pretty grating at times. Also she literally worships Chariot, whatever floats your witchy boat I guess.


And Chariot herself. She seemed pretty cool at first but as we learn more it seems her personality(if she had one) got extremely watered down and just…dull. Like I get it, she’s not a ‘hero’ or ‘famous’ anymore but to literally get rid of your personality and not really with any good reason other then “I realized what I did was hOrRiBle AnD I cAn’T fOrGiVe MySeLf so I became boring”. Cool cool. Pretty boring resolution for her “arc”.


There were more characters but I don’t feel like talking about them or remember much abut them LOL…the one science/modern witch lady…Croix I believe? She was so gimmicky it made me laugh. What a lady.


Overall, they were all pretty flat and boring once more and more episodes showed the m=not much was going to change, maybe the manga had better development?


ENJOYMENT:

6/10


It was just fine…fun to turn my brain off a little and watch cute girls try magic with teen drama and lots of yelling with nice animation. Wouldn’t watch again, if I did I would most likely just watch the first and last episodes and just skip like the whole middle LOL


OVERALL:

5/10

To quote my mom:

“That Akko girl sure does yell a lot of her lines”


She was and is very right about that.

As a casual viewer, Little Witch Academia’s went from the legendries OVAs that the show is based off of to being a Kill la Kill/Darling in the Franxx in disguised, and while both of them were very good show, they enjoyed a better focus, and ultimately much better writing that LITTLE WITCH ACADEMIA lacked to stand next to them.
Those who loved KILL LA KILL and DARLING IN THE FRANXX will definitely find LITTLE WITCH ACADEMIA similar. The cast contains a mix of unique characters and favorites archetypes with an interesting and developed world. It had a clear formula that worked before in KILL LA KILLand DARLING IN THE FRANXX where the first 13 episodes is a curve up for Akko, the main character, to slowly grows as the casts are introduced and the end goal. The later episodes were used to explore more about each character, and ultimately ends in space. Trigger-y! Importantly, Akko never fell into the archetype of the “fully geared main character who has beat everyone except the final boss”. There’s something humanizing about this, even though we all know that she will succeed. Then there’s also the quality of art and sound. They were of top quality and extremely consistent no matter the episode. It’s the kind of show that you would expect from Trigger, a high-quality anime that’s punchy, colorful, and a go-happy adventure.

What the show suffered from is, first, a lack of focus on Magic. As a show about witches, the spells, the magic presented were uninspiring, boring and underused; it was either used as a convenient plot device or simply not used at all! For example, only a handful of the spells were introduced earlier in the show, and one would expect more interesting spell or spell interactions to be performed. Instead, we see the same spell performed over and over again uninterestingly by though around Akko, or even not at all, like when (spoiler-ish) Naomi used her wand to enhance a sword and proceeded to poke her opponent down; why wouldn’t they just have a use simple spell? or how Ursula literally pulled out a light saber from her wand to fight; why? She’s a powerful witch! even Constantine no longer use any magic to build her tools, which was what made her special in the OVA; now she literally pulled out an MP5 (spoiler ends), and those were just to name a few. The daily activities and action sequence, while beautifully animated, had no magic about them, Ursula even did the Naruto run in one of the sequences. With the exception to episode 12 and 13, the entire 25 episodes of the show simply lacked the magic and importantly an imagination that were showed in  the OVAs.


However, all of this would’ve been fine if not for the low quality of writing of the show; Those who have watched the OVAs that inspired this show will find that this is most disappointing. While the show may have got more physical actions, it is the convoluted plot that Trigger built to create drama that made it tiresome.  The biggest one is (spoiler) Croix. What was the whole point of Croix in showing magic is believing in your heart? Akko was already a commoner. Of course, it would not have matter, as the plot is carried by its character, if the writing was not so subpar. No longer are there any subtly in the conversations or in the actions of characters to shows their intentions and personalities. In its place are unnecessarily drawn out conversations, or even unnecessary episodes that ultimately achieved nothing or could’ve been done in a shorter time. Take, for example, the original OVA from 2013. From how the girls talked to each other in their room, naturally expositing the world and their friendship, the little curtsy that Diana gave to Akko in the cafeteria, to the demeanor of Ursula while introducing the dungeon, to Diana and Akko interaction after the dragon was released, to how Ursula very briefly showed her identity, to Diana and Akko interaction about Chariot. In 22 minutes Sucy, Akko, Lotte, Diana, and Ursula had more personality and relationships developed between them than the first 13 episodes of the series. 


In the end, LITTLE WITCH ACADEMIA wanted to tell a shounen-esque story while its original OVAs an imaginative magical story, and that’s fine. However, its writing is a disappointment and that ultimately puts it below its OVAs and other Trigger show. It’s a shame, because when Trigger change to Akko from being bad with magic to struggling to use magic to the point of virtually having no magical capability at all, ironically, they also took the magic out of the show.


As a personal note, no anime has ever made me leave a review. There are many other problems with this show, but most are subjective and could've been carried with a better writing. I’m sure that there are other reviewers have already laid them out. I do not hate what they have changed about the the show, but just that it could be so much more than just another adventure anime. I suppose that I’m still very much in love with the 2 OVAs and if a season 3 ever comes out I would still watch it in hope to find that magic of the show again.

Some spoilers so bear with me.
Little Witch Academia at best can be summed up as a fun little show about friendship and adventure.
It begins with Akko attending at her first day at a magic school to become a witch and her dream is to become like her childhood idol Shiny Chariot so that she can make the world around her happy. She befriends Sucy and Latto as they go on many adventures of magic and wonder. 
Later on in the series, a threat emerges that could potentially plunge the world into total chaos. Akko, Sucy, Latto, and the rest of the witches team up tostop the menace and the world is saved from the threat and Akko learns what it truly means to have friends that are always there for you and she shows the world that magic still has a place in a world where magic is a nearly extinct art that has been largely forgotten by the masses.


The characters are really fun and imaginative and each have their own unique personalities that give the characters their own defining traits that shows each character's strong and weak points that give these characters a lot of depth. 


The animation is really fluid and lively too. You really don't see a lot of anime that has animation this good. Sadly due to the high cost of producing an anime, a lot of studios have to cut corners in order to not go over the given budget. So they really outdone themselves with the animation of Little Witch Academia that it's almost movie quality animation.


The soundtrack is also great too. It really fits with the tone and the theme of the series and they did a great job with the show's soundtrack because it does set the mood for the charm and setting of the series.


My only complaint that I have for this show is the story. The story isn't anything that groundbreaking or revolutionary. The story does start out okay at first, it does get a bit interesting during the middle of the show, and the ending could have been better. I wished they could have been a bit more original with the ending. How can I describe the ending? I won't go too much into detail but if you've seen how the Kid Buu Saga ends in Dragon Ball Z (you know, the ending where Mr. Hercule Satan call on the people of Earth to give Goku the energy he needs for the Spirit Bomb to defeat Kid Buu) then you've seen how Little Witch Academia ends. No really, they pulled a Dragon Ball Z as the ending for Little Witch Academia as part of the big battle that happens at the end of the show. I guess it was suppose to pay homage to Dragon Ball Z (because Little Witch Academia does make references to other works of fiction as well) but I still wished they could have been more original with the ending for this series.


Overall Little Witch Academia is a fun anime that's filled with magic, wonder, great characters, great animation, and a great soundtrack. The story could have been better but at least they tried their best to make this anime a fun show to watch even if it wasn't anything groundbreaking or revolutionary as far as entertainment is concerned.

This anime talks to me on so many different levels... I can't begin to describe the enjoyment I have watching this series.
The interesting combination of elements from cartoon and anime and the rich amount of design work put into the characters and the world somehow remind me of Avatar: The Last Airbender. Both shows make you live every emotion on the spectrum.
Every episode brings new and interesting material. I just completely love everything about this show.
-Every character (primary and secondary) are compelling. They are very likeable.
-The show has an episodic format without compromising progression of the main story. Every episode is fresh and there isvery good pacing.\n
-The dynamic between characters (esp. Akko & Diana)\n
-The animation's great, for an anime series, and the art direction isn't afraid from diverging from your standard anime.\n
-The OP and EDs are stunning. I am amazed by the visual effects and animations of the credits, especially.\n
-There are very good messages conveyed too, that personally resonate very strong with me!\n\n
I've watched enough media to discern poor and masterpiece content. From the first ten minutes of Little Witch Academia, I already knew I was in for something I'd love and remember for a very long time. And, "deep" into the series, I can't say this has changed one bit.\n\n

Little Witch Aca!! Overall it was a great show, pretty amazing animation throughout the whole show kinda paced a bit weirdly but  a fun watch! The characters were all simple and there was, generally a nice flow throughout the whole anime. I feel like episodes just focusing on the characters and their relationships did the best job. Its just pretty neat because most of the characters are likable and its fun to get to know more about them. The main plot is mostly pushed into the background for most episodes so we can continue to get to know the characters, which is kind ofwhat leads to all the later problems. Problems being the end,, which i don't think this is a spoiler but warning if it is: Its ending sucked a whole lot of ass. Too much is shoved in at once. A new character was introduced towards kinda abruptly and her interactions with other characters felt so off? She felt forced and her design is the most jarring if not interesting in the show which i'm not necessarily sure is a fault it just felt out of place. There's a lot of loose ideas thrown around that aren't fully addressed or flushed out like how certain machines operate, why certain things matter. *I'm gonna try to be as vague as possible* but for as many times as i had tried to watch it, whats the point of the moon scene. It feels thrown in for dramatic effect, or like a very unexplored idea. It might just be that I 'just don't get it' but when somethings leading up to one big thing, especially in a show that generally doesn't delve too deep into big ideas, the tone shift they tried to pull off was just bad.  I couldn't feel like i was enjoying what i was watching it, bc it didn't make sense. There were some cool concepts too, ideas present in the ova of a magic vs current tech struggle. At first the idea of magic taking a backseat to modern technology seems a little wild as, its fucking magic. But if magic had been around since forever of course its gonna seem outdated compared to phones that basically magic. There's this kinda B plot actually with a clash between witches and the rest of the world bc magic is outdated!! Which was a cool idea but they tried to resolve it too quickly. It felt like if they had a few more episodes and didn't have to follow a strict formulaic layout the ending would have suffered less.  Maybe all of that sounds nit picky or whatever you'd like to call it but it all adds up at the end making it feel very unsatisfying. Overall was still a good time.

This review has a summed up review at the top without any spoilers and a bigger review with spoilers after
Non-spoiler review:
Story: 9; Filled with great foreshadowing and amazing storylines, but with some plot flaws
Art: 10, I don't really know what to say. Trigger always makes amazing animation, but this is incredible.
Music: 9; I loved the first OP and ED, liked the second ones less. The rest of the music was great. The use of violin was perfect for the magical school vibe
Characters: 10; I liked every single character in this show. Except for Jasminka, she was alright. They all develop as characters and we learnmore about them. This is probably my favorite cast of characters in an anime. 

Enjoyment: 10; This is probably the show that I have enjoyed the most out of every single show a have seen. A combination of the characters, the story, and the art made it so fun to watch!


Overall: 10; Amazing show, lacking a tiny bit in its plot






Spoiler review: (beware, this review will probably be constructed horribly)


This is the second time watching this anime. I had several reasons to rewatch. The first was that I just loved it so much and I knew I had to rewatch it. Second, it was in a way the first anime I had watched (Before I had watched animes cause I wanted to watch animated series, not specifically anime which was my reason the first time. Third, my critical abilities have improved since the first-time watch it. So here we go, my review for LWA


Story: 

This plot had many things that I loved. I loved the way that they don't keep Ursula real name a secret just so that the reveal can be in the last episodes. If someone knows that she is really chariot and no one around them can't know about it, then they're going to say her real name. Example, when it's the blue moon night and Ursula finds Akko in the cave. The green leaf witch says Chariot instead of Ursula cause there's no reason for her to say her fake name, Ursula. 

I also loved the message in the show. I don't really know if I want to call it a message. But the story, in my opinion, I kind of about a wrong way of idolizing someone. Something you can easily see in the show is that Akko loved Chariot and wants to be like her. She was basically perfect to her. But then she hears that she is the reason that she can't use magic, she wasn't perfect. I haven't really seen a show about this. How idolization can go too far. 

Next, character presentation. This was actually really well made. First Akko, in the first scene that she is in we see that she is happy, energetic and overall positive. This perfectly shows what personality she has. Next, Sucy. The first she is in she keeps quiet and she pranks Akko as she follows her. Again, this shows perfectly who she is. Next, Lotte. She seems to be awkward and shy, but not to the extreme. The presentations I would have liked to be better was Constanze and Jasminka. They are introduced in the episode where they first learn to fly. But the way that they introduce them was by making Jasminka eat some chips and make Constanze build something. I wasn't really a fan of this way of introduction. But in the next scene we see that Constanze has upgraded her broom with machineries. This would have been a way better way to introduce Constanze.

Next, the foreshadowing. Wow, the first scene had an incredible amount of foreshadowing. You could see Diana, you could see how the magic in the audience escaped everyone and you could see one of those red cube monsters. You can even see in Ursula's face reactions when someone speaks badly of Chariot. 

Next, how it makes sense that Akko become friends with Andrew and Diana. Both of they're families are of high stature. They don't really get encouragements from anyone, but when Akko comes she changes that. She is the puzzle piece that both needed in their life. You can even see in the second episode when Akko makes all the butterflies bloom that Diana sees chariot in her.

But there also many small things I loved about the story. Like how Sucy is basically only in the school to get more mushrooms. The first day of the school again presents the characters very good. How Sucy is only focused on the chemistry class, Lotte is focused on everything and Akko finds everything boring cause Chariot was the person to introduce magic into her life. How Akko becomes quieter about Chariot after hearing how annoying Lottes fandom could be. How you could see a big contrast between Akko's and Lotte's idolization, how one wants to be exactly like their idol and one doesn't. How Akko's and Amanda's friendship starts with their hate for Diana. That there's a reason why Akko is worse at magic than her classmates more than her not being raised as a witch. Episode 8 was just great, had so many creative ideas. The theme of Akko trying to bring back magic like it was in the golden magic ages. How Ursula can give perfect advice for Akko cause she knows what she has to do to get all the words. The end of the "first season" was great. How Akko showed the school that you don't need to make something the same way every time to make something amazing. You get why Akko likes Croix, cause Croix wants to change a lot in the school which Akko admires, cause she likes change too. 


But since I gave the story a 9 I had a few problems. Most of them were very small, but here are some bigger ones:


In episode 10 Andrew and Diana seem to have a very good relationship. But the last time we saw them together it didn't feel that way.

I still don't know what Croix was a teacher for.

How did Constanze get a mega room under her dorm? Did the school allow that?

They could have been more subtle of why Croix is trying to make sure Akko doesn't find all the words.

Croix lied to Akko about when the tree would spread the poison, and Akko still trusts her

Seems a little weird how mad everyone got for a soccer match. I mean, riots for several days. I don't think that would ever happen

Why was it Diana that was with Akko when destroying the missile? Why not Lotte and Sucy? They were your friends from the beginning. 




Animation:

Honestly, this is probably my favorite animation I have ever seen in an anime (tied with your name). It felt like every episode had a moment where the animation would completely steal the show. Trigger has always had great animation, but this was incredible.


Music:

I loved the first OP and ED. The second OP and ED weren't as good. The use of violin was great in the show.


Characters:

This is probably my favorite cast of characters I have seen in an anime, and here's why. 

First the three main characters. Akko isn't one-sided, she had development and was very likable, making her into a very good character. Then we have Lotte who is a little more one-sided but definitely not too one-sided. I would have liked more development for her, other than that she was really good. Then there was Sucy, wow. I loved her. She is probably the funniest anime characters I have seen. Just her being there and saying something in character would be funny. She was very one-sided and not very developed but I think I liked that about her. Then we have some side-characters that are all great. They're all developed (except Jasminka) and have good personalities. I really liked Andrew and Diana's development throughout the show. And I just want to say how good Chariot was. She was nice to everyone, had a cool backstory but she has made mistakes that people have been affected by. 


Enjoyment: This was amazingly fun to watch. It was funny, had many emotional moments and the animation makes it good to look at. 


Other: 

The voice actor choice was perfect for sucy!

Constanze has a gun. How can a character get better?

OMG THEY DID A YOUR NAME REFRENCE!!!


Overall: I think this is an amazing show that you should definitely watch

Why You Should Watch Little Witch Academia
I’ve fallen in love with the Netflix series Little Witch Academia.
LWA follows Akko Kagari who, despite having no natural aptitude for magic, enrolls at Luna Nova Witchcraft Academy to follow in the footsteps of her hero, the legendary witch Shiny Chariot. What I absolutely adore about LWA is how it perfectly combines elements of Western and Eastern animation/storytelling. On the Western side, it’s obvious the premise of the show was inspired by Harry Potter. Like Harry, Akko herself has no magic experience before being whisked away to magic school where she meets a blonde Malfoy-esque rival character in Diana,complete with her own Crabbe and Goyle equivalents. There are even little references to Harry Potter sprinkled in: magic is powered by the Sorcerer’s Stone and there’s a broomstick called the Shooting Star. On the Eastern side, many of the characters are rooted in Japanese archetypes including Genki (Akko), Meganekko (Lotte), Kamidere (Diana), and Bokukko (Amanda). However, their characterizations are subtle enough to overcome cultural barriers and fit perfectly into a Western style story. This East meets West style can even be seen in the animation and art which are reminiscent of early Disney, conveying a sense of wonder and energy yet still being rooted in anime aesthetics - imagine mixing The Sorcerer’s Apprentice from Fantasia and giving it an anime coat of paint. Add to that excellent acting in either English or Japanese and this melting pot of cultures can be enjoyed by anyone and is the perfect show to watch with younger siblings. 


Ultimately if Avatar the Last Airbender is what happens when Western creators look eastward for inspiration, Little Witch Academia is what happens when Eastern creators look westward. Do yourselves a solid and watch this show!


HOW TO WATCH

There are 2 specials, which essentially act as pilots, and a 25-episode series. If you’re already sold I recommend starting with the specials (Little Witch Academia, followed by the Enchanted Parade), then watching the series. If not, start with the series (which I feel does a better job at selling the series) then go back to the specials.

It's one of those anime where the theme is cliche, but the execution is unique, and I like it. There are a lot of references in this series which I enjoyed and after comparing it to the movie(2013), I am glad that they totally changed the script and such.
Final Fantasy VI(5th) and Mother 3(1st) are one of my top 5 favorite video games of all time and if I am to combine them(plus a good protagonist that doesn't much complain the whole freakin time), this will be the outcome, and I'm not mad at all. Both of these games are masterpieces not only in thegaming industry, but also in my heart, so the story will receive a 10


Art and sound are very good(8). Not that great as to other anime during their time, but it's very good. It somehow follows the theme of the series.


Character, all of them are lovable, one of them may be like one of those cliche bullies, but there's character development there, so it's a 10


I enjoyed the series as much as I enjoyed playing Mother 3(minus the tears because this anime doesn't made me cry), so the enjoyment is OBVIOUSLY a 10


Overall, I'll say that Little Witch Academia is a mediocre-to-masterpiece anime. If I am to watch the movie first, I would totally not find this anime series interesting, but I'm really glad they changed the whole plot.


P.S Disney is not anime.

I'll keep this short.
For those interesting in watching, I'd recommend it. It has a nostalgic feel and a cliche main character. If you've seen Black Clover, the main character is just like that. Very similar to a typical shonen.
I'll say that the idea of the story is great, but the execution seemed flawed. That's probably because the episodes were limited. A majority of the episodes feel like filler, but that is because there is no true objective at least until we are near the end. But, even then, the main antagonist does not really seem like one either.
One thing that makes the main character bothunique and annoying is how she gains new powers. To avoid spoiling, I'll just say that she can become stronger by doing every day tasks and getting lucky. Most of her big power ups happen in what feels like filler episodes. Nearly every single important moment feels out of place for me.\n\n
Despite some all of these flaws, I couldn't help but smile at the main character's attitude. It felt genuine, which is something most cannot pull off. I would still recommend watching this to anyone, but I would highly recommend it to a younger audience.

ทุกคนก็คงมีเรื่องในดวงใจก็ตัวเองละครับ ผมก็เรื่องนี้เเหละ ไม่งั้นผมจะมาเขียนให้เสียเวลาทำไม เรื่องนี้ทำให้ผมมีเเรงบันดาลใจจริงๆ เเละปกติที่ผมมองโลกในเเง่ร้ายอย่างรุนเเรง ก็เหมือนว่าจะผมให้หัวใจผมนั้นสว่างขึ้นเเละมองในทางที่ดีขึ้น อยากจะขอบคุณเรื่องนี้จริงๆ ขอบคุณที่ทำมาให้คนอย่างผมดู ^w^/


ก็จบไปเเล้วสำหรับการบ่นให้คนอ่าน นี้คือรีวิวเเรกเเละอาจจะเป็นรีวิวสุดท้าย ที่ผมมาเขียนเพราะอยากถ่ายทอดความรู้สึกที่มีต่อเรื่องนี้
