-THIS IS MY TRUE FEELING THANK YOU FOR READING THIS REVIEW-

-First time review and maybe it last review-

Overall - 7:
This anime was beautiful to look at, and alright to watch. The characters were great, but the plot was boring and relies on the audience accepting what the show does, weather or not it makes a whole lot of sense.
Story - 5:
Like most shows that have magic, you can't possibly hope to have everything make sense. If you want to have a fluid story that isn't just 20 minutes of explaining you can focus on the how of everything, and this show knows that. I don't really like shows with magic and that is why, but there is another issue, at least forme when it comes to this anime, and that is the overall story being too simple. Most of the episodes focus on single things, some of which loosely tie in to the overall story. There's nothing necessarily wrong with this, I just don't like it as much as a well written coherent story where each episode is part of a large story. The ending was good, simple, somewhat predictable, but great nonetheless.


Art - 10:

Studio trigger's art is always amazing, this show is no exception. From the simple scenes of the characters in their room to the amazing action packed fight sequences, the art never fails to be amazing.


Sound - 5:

I'm honestly pretty disappointed in the soundtrack, they have literally one good melody and most of the good songs in the soundtrack are rehasings of it. The soundtrack does it's job, but it could have been a lot better.


Character - 10:

I'm very impressed with the level of character diversity in this show. Just design wise the characters look quite different from one another, and their personalities are also very unique to who they are. The character interactions take up a good portion of the anime, and that is probably the best part (at least when it's not essentially the same character interaction done again and again because the plot has it be that way.)


Enjoyment - 7:

I had a good time watching this show, but it didn't really have me wanting to watch, just one more episode every time. It was more of a "I should watch an episode of that now, since I have time". The show was always great to look at, but episode to episode there wasn't much that made me eager to come back for more.

Little Witch Academia! Damn. For all the anime i started watching without knowing anything prior, this one really takes the top! Since i started re-watching anime, i was kinda lost because i was out of touch with anime for so long. I've only briefly seen few recommendations here and there. So, i decided to try something different, that is to watch new anime series/ adaptations without knowing or hearing anything prior, only going into it with the knowledge of the synopsis. Anime series like Gabriel Dropout was nice, and Demi-chan wa Kataritai was ok, and then... i came across Little Witch Academia. To be reallyhonest, i was not expecting much since i never even knew it existed and the artwork did nothing to increase my hopes for this show. Oh, how wrong i was. It was great! Better than great, it was awesome, and seriously under-rated a 25 episode show. 


Plotline 8/10


The plot starts off as many others do, with the main character dreaming to aim for the top of the field, just like their idols... except this character was hopelessly useless... at mostly EVERYTHING, and had horrible luck and an aggressive attitude to boot. Nevertheless, this useless character is what made the story interesting. Since she is not overpowered, she uses her quick wits and passion to solve problems that skilled talent would not. This introduces a kind of witty comedy that made me eager for more! The plot itself doesn't really get under way until well in the middle of the series. But honestly, it didn't really bother me since the pre-slice of life episodes were really fun to watch! The story itself actually isn't that bad either. What started as a quest to find an idol turned out to be something much more and to be fair, the climax was much surprising to me. The great thing about the plot is that it doesn't turn out to be needlessly complicated as many anime does, especially those involving magic. The story is simple, yet engaging, and also adds in twist of wittiness and ingenious methods to make it more interesting, all the while wrapping it perfectly into one ending in one season. To be honest, i hope they didn't have a 2nd season just because of how nicely everything ended.


Art: 8/10


One of the more shocking review sections, even for me. When one sees the artwork cover for Little Witch Academia, one doesn't even imagine the graphic is anything to be admired. Yet, for some reason, it all works really well! I was so shocked to find out how well it worked out for the entire theme of the show. Sure, i know that the graphics seem really out of date for something in 2017 but here's the thing! It actually works with the show! In contrast, if the graphics were to be modernised, it would actually RUIN the show and its setting. The jumpy characters, the relaxing atmosphere and the spells are all nicely fitted into the artwork, creating a casual yet nicely framed environment.


Music 8/10


Not much to say here, i like the music. Sure, it's not Re-zero material, but it's quite pleasing to hear. Oh, the one that made all the difference! The ending. Here's an honest fact about me. Usually, when an anime ends, i skip without even listening to the ending theme, maybe only watching it once for the ending credits animation. But, in Little Witch Academia, the credits are special. In every single credit sequence, iconic scenes from the current episodes are always shown. I kinda liked it and always stay back just to relieve the episode for another 1 to 2 min or so. I think it's a nice little gesture for viewers to relax in accompaniment to the music.


Character: 7/10


All of the characters were lovable, with decent development, and character traits that were distinguishable even without speaking (literally if you know what i mean ;) ). None of them were annoying and that is the most important point for me as them being annoying would severely ruin this show. Although, there were 3 characters i had to mention that were nothing but the best characters for me in the show. SPOILERS AHEAD:



***

Akko - Main character, jumpy, unlucky, sucks at magic, and has a great 

          passion, ingenious wits. I just adore her! Even though she fits right into the misread, mischievous, misconduct and miserable main character category, something about her just makes her all the more different from all of them! Her hardworking self makes me want to cheer, her passion moves me, her wittiness makes me laugh, her angry pouts are so adorable and her transformations are so CUTE! I mean, don't deny it! Her metamorphy faciesse is simply CUTE!


Diana - Cold, Cool, Talented All-round Rich girl. What? Sounds like a snob?

           Good sir, Diana is the BEST! She's not even half an inch snob!! She's helpful, kind, often misunderstood, and hides a nature of hers she didn't want to show others just because she doesn't want to burden them! I never hated her once, from the beginning till the end. Her episode was just tear jerking.


Shiny Chariot / Ursula - Man, i could relate to her so much. Her character 

                                  backdrop just goes to show that talented people are the often the ones that feel most stressed and troubled behind their smiles. Often burden with wanting to make people happy, she ended up hurting more people than she had intended, and having to retire from her idol career and abandon her dream to watch people smile. She is the true definition of a fallen angel.


*** SPOILERS END HERE


Enjoyment (Personal Enjoyment) :


Even with no knowledge on the show whatever, this show was really great. It hit me hard with laughter the first episode and with so much feels by the end of the 25 episodes run. I enjoyed it a whole lot, and it made me understand just what people mean by there's a whole lot of under rated anime and not just popular ones like Naruto, One Piece, and Fate series. Honestly, i don't think you will regret watching Little Witch Academia.

Do you ever wonder "What if Harry Potter were actually good?" Okay, maybe that's too harsh to Harry Potter. What about "What if Harry Potter were an anime?" Um, maybe I'm getting off point here. Anyway, it has magic, so that reminds me of Harry Potter.
Do you know that part at the end of Just Cause 2 where Rico grapples between missiles while they're in the air and he has to diffuse them before they blow up an oil field? Yeah, that's a pretty cool scene, and this show has just as climactic an ending, I won't spoil it here.
But overall, what makes this showgreat is the comedy. It's refreshingly actually funny. I don't watch that much comedy anime because I don't find it that interesting as a general rule. It tends to lose my interest very quickly. But this one managed to remain interesting. The episodes are mainly self-contained, but towards the end there starts to be more of a continuous plot. Despite this, each episode manages to be interesting, and drives forward the characters' relationships. By the end of the show you grow to know and love a large number of them, even the side characters. Most characters have at least one episode about them.\n\n
The art, of course, is excellent. As to be expected from Trigger. It's not as incredible as Kill La Kill, but it's solid throughout, especially in the character design. Each character is distinctive in a way that matches their personality.\n\n
Overall, I'd strongly recommend it. It's no Madoka Magica, but then again, few things are.

"A believing heart is my magic." Little Witch Academia is not just a show about magic, it is a magical show in itself. Most of the show takes on an episodic format where Akko and her friends are cast into a whole range of problems that need solving. The story is masterfully pieced together so that these episodic tales become highly relevant to the overarching plot of the show.
Akko's journey to meet Shiny Chariot is one full of charm. The world of Luna Nova is full of breathtaking environments and the team at Trigger have created a truly magical world. Trigger's unique and playful animationtechniques have been used to their full effect to make the characters and the world they inhibit as vibrant as they can be. The show is full of references to western media and also previous Trigger works.


The music is fantastic and every track is full of the essence of adventure. The main theme in particular made me reach Kill La Kill levels of excitement. 


It's always refreshing to see a character who has to struggle to become good at something. Akko is hardly witch material, but she endures the mockery of those around her so that she can fulfill her dream of meeting her idol and using magic to make people happy. I think some of that magic may have seeped into reality, because I was certainly happy when watching this show.


Trigger continues to show that it is possible to create a strong female cast of characters, with each one being distinct and memorable. Just like the shows before it LWA does not hold back on its craziness and it makes this a series to remember. All fans can hope for now is that a season 2 happens.

I really liked the series. It is of these animes that, although the story is simple and without many complications (who is Chariot is obvious from the beginning), the development of the plot and the characters catches to you immediately. Also, being a Netflix, I love that I had from the beginning a dub to Latin American Spanish that, although I do not know if I consider the best I've seen, if I seemed very good, leaving each character perfect the voice they had.
==========================================
Me gusto mucho la serie. Es de esos animes que, aunque la historia es simple y sin muchas complicaciones (quien es Chariotes obvio desde el comienzo), el desarrollo de la trama y los personajes te atrapa de inmediato. Ademas, al ser de Netflix, me encanto que tuviese desde el comienzo un doblaje al español latinoamericano que, aunque no se si considerarlo el mejor que he visto, si me parecio muy bueno, quedandole a cada personaje perfecto la voz que tenian.

Where to begin? Maybe to where I know this anime first. 
This anime started as a stand-alone movie, if I am not mistaken it had two movies where they are introducing the characters that we will meet later on the series.
After the series started, fans that have found this before, will know that it doesn't follow the movies. It started from the start to much my dismay. Anyhow let's get back to rating.
Story (10) - Since I was excited about this series, I know that the anime will not disappoint me, and I was right, although the first episode had me confused, it took mea while to realize the studio decided to start from scratch but it stayed quite the same, only different interpretation. I tried predicting about the reason why the main character couldn't do certain magic, but at the end. It got me by surprise, this anime never fails to amaze you.


Art (10) - Pretty much original, each characters are different from each other and yet they are still easily to be remembered. Aside from the characters, I really like how they do their scenery, the lightning, it gives us more atmospheric feeling and it doesn't bore us out. 


Sound (8) - Well, the soundtracks make the Shiny Rod amazing, but I don't really remember much of it because I was set focused on the episode, meaning I enjoy the story more than concentrating to the soundtrack.


Character (10) - Well, plenty of character development here, but we have a Mary Sue character (Diana), but later on the series, she has given a background story as well, where it makes you feel bad about what you have thought about her in the beginning. It made sure that the really important characters get backstories. Even minor characters, they have some small background stories that are not really quite relevant to the series yet it was there, to know why they are like that. 


Enjoyment (10) - There is never an episode where I had to say, "I will just skip some part of this anime", I tend to do that, but it never gave me that feeling. I was constantly curious how it will end.


Overall - Well, certainly an anime that has the Harry Potter vibe on it, but this anime is unique. You don't see a lot of anime that has a school and witches on it that actually make sense.


Thank you for reading this review!

Have a nice day everyone!

And I guess we have another winner here coming from Anime Mirai. For those not in the know, Little Witch Academia was originally made as an animated short for an annual Japanese animator's project called Anime Mirai for aspiring young animators to create their own unique works. The short's popularity with fans eventually led to a Kickstarter-funded film project to be brought about in 2015 and later led to this TV anime that aired, the second one made from an Anime Mirai short since the 2015 premiere of Death Parade. Focused on a young girl named Akko aspiring to be a witch in spite oflacking any aptitude in magic, our main heroine enrolls into the Luna Nova Magical Academy to receive witch training, getting caught up in some of the antics of her classmates, and trying to seek out magical words connected to a mysterious magic wand called the Shiny Rod that belonged to Akko's idol, the stage magician Shiny Chariot.


This TV anime expands a great deal on exploring the world of Little Witch Academia with the large amount of time that the format provides it. Besides Akko, a good number of the witches at Luna Nova get a good deal of focus and development into their characters that help flesh them out. There's enough time for the TV format as such where some new characters are even brought into the series with witches and non-magic folk that include new witch instructor Croix and young aristocrat Andrew Hanbridge. The series even takes the time to explore how magic works within the world of the series, with a major story element in the series being magic becoming increasingly scarce for use by witches and any spiritual familiars that draw upon it to sustain themselves, thus affecting the status of Luna Nova Academy.


On the subject of Akko and the mentioned magic crisis, these two mentioned situations are consistently entwined with one another throughout much of Little Witch Academia. With Akko gaining possession of the Shiny Rod, she comes to discover that she has to unlock specific words to it in order to tap more into its powers. Without spoiling too much, the discovery of the words to the Shiny Rod are connected to Akko's character development throughout the series where she tries to defy the magical traditions of Luna Nova to show she can gain the power to become a witch through hard work, perseverance, faith in one self, and trusting in others. These story elements take on more prominence in the show's second half when more about the Shiny Rod's purpose and origins are revealed, and what connection it has to Akko's idol, Shiny Chariot (who is revealed quite early on to be much closer to Akko than she would expect).


Setting aside these serious elements, what perhaps makes Little Little Academia one of the year's best titles for me is how unique it sticks out. It avoids going into many of the typical storytelling cliches that many modern anime would lazily get into and offers a Western-inspired look at a world of magic that is rarely focused on within many anime titles. In addition, it strikes a nice balance of comedy and drama to focus on the developments of the witches at Luna Nova and its main plot of Akko's quest to learn more about the Shiny Rod, while also being very accessible to Western audiences with its family-friendly content and optimistic themes.


Overall, Little Witch Academia made for one of the best viewing experiences for an anime for the year thus far thanks to its unique premise on Western-influenced magic and the developments concerning Akko and the Shiny Rod. Being very accessible to wide audiences with its premise and having a nice balance of comedy, adventure, and drama, the series is a definite recommendation I would make as a fan and one that could also be used as a possible "gateway drug" to draw in new or casual fans to the world of anime.

This will be the best show that no one will watch this season. If you are not aware, there is a big commotion with Netflix only just releasing LWA on their streaming platform, and when they did, it was only half the season.
That aside, this show is simply charming. I have always said that Trigger is the best at selling a feeling. Whatever Trigger wants you to feel, it makes you feel that. If that's what you want from anime, just stop reading and go watch the show however you can. Or you can keep reading, no spoilers ahead.
Everything about the show adds to theenjoyment. The characters that you loved from the OVA and the movie are still here and are more consequential than expected. Its a nice surprise to see a show that starts with the intention to make a well written story and be one cohesive whole. Honestly, just go watch the show, especially if you want a fun warm time.


And I feel I should be more critical now, because the show is not perfect. In the grading portion, I gave it a seven, not because the show is poorly written, because it, like the rest of LWA's components are simply outstanding, but the plot is about the least original part of the show. There are twists and turns that make you go oh, but for me, I saw it all coming.


Of course, the answer to that is that this show isn't about the plot but about the friendships Akko builds with the other character, but I disagree. Sure, the other properties seemed to do the whole "friendship is magic" angle, but in the show, we are treated with themes of creating your own self value, and knowing the world and the role you can play in it. The phrase from the show, "Akko doesn't believe in miracles, but she has always believed in herself" comes to mind. But back to why I gave this portion a seven, this kind of story necessitated a stronger plot focus and I feel that is a shortcoming of the show. I think most would agree that they didn't watch because they cared about the plot.


Other than that, the show is fantastic. Its visually intense and you find yourself looking at everything, whether it is the lore steeped vistas they locale or the titles of the books that the characters have in their rooms. There is a clear astronomical amount of detail poured into the show and all of Triggers strengths, visuals, design, action and creating characters you want to succeed.


Any more to say about the show is unnecessary. If you are a Trigger fan, its Kill la Kill wearing robes and practicing magic. If you're not a fan of Trigger's past works, this is still a beautifully crafted show that any reviewer worth his words would recommend. 


There is something here for everyone, and I am sure you can find what you want with this show.

"A believing heart is [the] magic!" -- spoiler free, as best as can be
I believe this phrase sums up the show fairly well, ('the' in place of 'your' ofc). 
It's fairly easy to pick apart this show, and find the many apparent flaws in the main four categories provided by MyAnimeList. That is, there are quite a few things lacking in the story and character (development) department, as well as (but notably less) in the art and sound aspects. But looking at this show from any other angle than holistically does it a major disservice. 
I'll avoid a simple regurgitation of the plot, but Ido need to add a brief synopsis in order to aid my review- So, there's a girl named Atsuko Kagari (Akko), who stumbles upon a make-shift hogwarts. And, much like my man Harry Potter, she's enveloped by a world of magic completely unfamiliar to her that she must traverse. And with the help of her friends, she will fulfill her destiny and become a great witch, following in the footsteps of her idol Dumbledore-- and that's what I believe is the real catch of the show. 


Tying back into the quote I highlighted earlier, Akko, aside from the whole contrived destiny thing, is the epitome of the underdog and there is no greater elation I feel than being able to root for the underdog. It is such a relatable feeling to see someone start from nothing, and slowly (painfully slow, at times) become stronger, and I genuinely enjoy watching any show with that archetype-- no matter how cliche it is. It's not just Akko either, all of the characters (well, most) are lacking something, that prevents them from being pretentious extras, that waste screen time, but instead admirable individuals with their own quirky, yet amiable, personalities. This passive fervor, led by the eccentric Akko doesn't make each episode ground-breaking, but heartwarming. An exceptional take on the classic "the fun is in the journey, not the destination."


...Which actually leads to some of my gripes with the show. As much as I would like to say otherwise, I'd be lying to myself (and y'all), if I didn't say there were quite a few problems that I felt arose with the show. I'll try to explain myself well, while relatively spoiler-free.


The story felt contrived. I would have honestly enjoyed stand-alone episodes, with a supernatural slice-of-life-esque feel, much like the first half of the show. That's not the say that her "destiny" didn't make sense, it's just that at times it felt a lot more like her "fate" than a "destiny." 


To clarify, I have no problem with her being "the chosen one," but that doesn't mean every problem that arises should be conveniently solved with recently learned magic. Now, to be fair, it was highly unlikely to begin with that Akko would ever drastically fail-- it would have created drastic, dark undertones to an otherwise shiny, sublime, sparkle-drenched universe. And I don't think it would have been as impactful Madoka Magica, anyway. 


This, coupled with what I felt were severely rushed episodes, raises the question of "Why even create these problems in the first place?" It really takes away from the aforementioned charm of an underdog story, when the underdog is presented with a problem, and it's solved in the same episode (or early in the next) with some super convenient power because 'plot'. They try to defend it by her "learning a lesson," but no. It just- no.


In addition, some of the characters that I fell in love with in the movie, got little to no screen time in pursuit of this one-sided war of a plot (yes you, Constanze Amalie von Braunschbank Albrechtsberger). Even the two best friends come and go at the drop of a hat. 


In contrast, the art is breathtaking. The style is unique, and whimsical, and really adds to the childlike wonder that I think the writer wanted to create. The OST is outstanding, really, it emphasizes the vibrancy of our heroine's(s') journey, while adding just a hint mystery as if to say, in it's own way, "Next stop, everywhere!"  If you haven't yet listened to the different soundtracks, I would highly suggest you do so-- starting with Chariot's Theme. (Just looked it up, most of the OST is copyright on Y----be)


Overall, I'd say it's worth a watch. Don't expect anything momentous like the next Neon Genesis, or Madoka Magica, but instead be swept off your feet with an effervescent take on the classic hero's journey.

The qualification of the story is 9/10, It's a good story although with a mistake, a bit of stuffing in a few chapters, chapters where the series does not progress, but still so non-fun


Characters: I do not know what to say about the characters, although Akko, Diana, Croix, Ursula-sensei, are the characters that gradually develop in the series, leave other characters behind (Akko's friends or the directors) Give them a chapter focused on them, but, it's just that and already


Art: Interesting and very well done, with fluid animation, and Harry Potter style backgrounds that never change


Little Witch Academy is a highly recommended series if you want to see some magic, comedy and why not ?, a little action Overall rating 8/10. Believing is magic

Watching Little Witch Academia has been so extremely enjoyable, and somehow nostalgic, that it reminds me of the first time I finished Arcana Famiglia, and it makes itself difficult to put into words.
I just realized, now that I finished it, that the reason for the connection is that I legitimately care about the characters, they feel real, to a certain point, which is not to mean the art style is exactly realistic, but it is beautiful nonetheless, truly the work of Studio Trigger. The plot itself is also not overly complex, in a good way, and is probably going to make it easier to recommendand describe vocally then, let's say, FMA:B, or even the original FMA (Which is probably my only complaint regarding anything to do with FMA).

Little witch academia was a great show to be invested in this season; it was unique, not too intense and overall a good, relaxing but still vibrant show to watch. I post this review one episode away from the final with the context that I have watched all of the movies. 
Story: 6/10
Honestly, Little witch academia's weak point is it's story telling; it was not bad by any means, but was in no way gripping either. Near the end it gets better story wise (no spoilers) but the anime is pretty episodic; Akko goes on adventures, develops her skills as a witch, helps others witha running motive-nothing special but definitely more suited as a tv series this way, though admittedly, some episodes stood out more than others. Just don't expect a ground breaking running plot or anything.


Art: 7/10

I personally liked the art, it wasn't glittery and detailed like you'd see in most anime but it really made the animation feel alive. The characters were expressive, the movements fluid, and pretty much easy on the eyes to look at. (I may be biased though, I watched videos of how the animation was made)


Sound: 8/10

The opening and ending songs were very catchy and fun to listen to. It definitely fits the vibe of the show well: childish, magical and vivid.


Character: 6/10

I liked the characters but alot of them didn't stand out to me as much as others. There were a few episodes focused on each character individually, but I just couldn't find it in me to appreciate all of them (maybe I did at one point, but then forgot later). A few characters had their time to shine throughout the show but I felt as if some were a bit weak considering they were meant to be reoccurring characters. 


Enjoyment: 8/10


Overall, I really liked Little Witch academia and it remained one of the shows I was most invested in this season, despite there being highly competitive series like boku no hero and attack on titan. The show is a nice watch of you don't want too much drama or something too intense to watch in your spare time. Has a nice touch of nostalgia too.

Rash, clumsy and happy-go-lucky "Akko" is a normal human girl inspired to become a witch after watching a magical performance by the witch, Chariot. By chance she manages to obtain the Shiny Rod from the forbidden forest, the same rod that Chariot had used before disappearing and she suddenly finds herself capable of some powerful magic. Along the way she befriends the mischievous poison mushroom loving Suzy and timid Lotte. Together, they start the new term at the famous Luna Nova Academy for witches as Akko strives to be like Chariot despite magic growing less appealing to the modern day world by the day.
The showwhich started of as a crowd-funded short film, feels very much like the action comedy you'd expect from Trigger featuring a silly cast of characters. I guess you could say it's a different kind of "magical girl" show. Right from the very first episode you're already laughing away at the antics Akko gets up to that throws her into trouble's way and all the silly comical reactions. You'd probably recognise some familiar styles from the studio too, especially the sparkly stars.


Granted it's not a serious show, I think the only things that stops me from recommending it is the world setting and pacing. Even though it tries to deviate from the common magical fantasy setting with silly ideas such as witches using machinery instead of magic, it's not that exciting to look at.


For the first half it kind of felt like a slice-of-life show (about witches in training of course) and sometimes it felt like I was watching a Nickelodeon cartoon from my childhood days so not quite as entertaining... The main plot does finally pick up traction by the second half of the show and as cheezy as it maybe, the wrap-up was great but the overall pacing and direction just felt too slow. Kind of like that long climb up a roller coaster except this climb was too long and I almost lost interest. Maybe not one of Trigger's better shows.


On another note, Diana really looks like Luna Lovegood from Harry Potter, lol. And if you do watch this, do look out for "Marks & Sponcers" if you're familiar with British stores. The second ED, "Invisible Wings" is also a great theme song.
